'''ANSI C12.20''' is an [[ANSI]] standard that describes an American National Standard for Electricity Meters - accuracy and performance.
The C12.20 standard established the physical aspects and performance criteria for a meter's [[accuracy class]]. It refines certain details in [[ANSI C12.1]] and [[ANSI C12.10]].
The existing ANSI accuracy classes for electric meters are: * Class .5 - having ± 0.5% accuracy. * Class .2 - having ± 0.2% accuracy.
Outside North America, [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] standards are used for electric meters.
== See also ==
* [[Electricity meter]] * ANSI C12.10, American National Standard for Physical Aspects of Watthour Meters. * ANSI C12.1, American National Standard for Electric Meters, Code for Electricity Metering
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100526093854/http://www.nema.org/stds/c12-20.cfm The ANSI C12.20 standard at NEMA]

{{unreferenced|date=July 2010}} '''Aerobic granular reactor''' is a type of waste treatment facility.
==Overview== [[Sewage treatment]] plants (STP) based on [[activated sludge]] often cover large surface areas, necessitated mainly by the large [[settling tank]]s. To build compact STP’s, [[biomass]] can be grown as [[biofilms]] on a carrier material, or as fast settling [[Aerobic granulation|aerobic granular sludge]] without a carrier. Recent research showed the advantages of a discontinuously fed system, in which it is possible to grow stable granulated sludge under aerobic conditions.
Simultaneous [[Chemical oxygen demand]], and [[Nitrogen]] and [[Phosphorus]] removal, can be easily integrated in a discontinuous fed system. Because of the high settling capacity of the granules, the use of a traditional settler is unnecessary. Therefore the installation can be built very compact, needing only 20% of the surface area of conventional activated sludge systems.
==See also== *[[List of waste water treatment technologies]] *[[Aerobic granulation]] *[[Membrane bioreactor]]
==External links== *[http://www.stowa-selectedtechnologies.nl/Sheets/Sheets/Aerobic.Granular.Sludge.Process.html Aerobic granular sludge process]

The group also has a significant presence in printing, plantations, power generation, financial services, IT, BPO/KPO sector, elevator agency services, garments, and property development. Aitken Spence has been recognised by [[Forbes]] as one of the most successful publicly traded companies with annual sales under US$1 billion outside of the United States, for three consecutive years.{{cite web | last = Aitken Spence| title = About Us| publisher = Aitken Spence| url = http://www.aitkenspence.com/about_us/hotels_logistics_power_sri_lanka.asp | accessdate=17 January 2012 }} In 2012, Aitken Spence was adjudged the top winner of the Best Corporate Citizen Award in 2017 and 2012 presented by the [[Ceylon Chamber of Commerce]] and has retained the title for 11 consecutive years.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence bags Best Corporate Citizen Award 2012 | newspaper = Daily Mirror | location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 13 November 2012 | url = http://www.dailymirror.lk/business/other/23439-aitken-spence-wins-best-corporate-citizen-award-2012-.html| accessdate=13 November 2014}}{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence wins Best Coporate Citizen Award 2017 | newspaper = Daily FT | location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 30 November 2017 | url = http://www.ft.lk/front-page/Aitken-Spence-wins--Best-Corporate-Citizen-Sustainability-Award-2017-/44-644258| accessdate= 17 January 2018}} The company is one of the first signatories to the UN's [[United Nations Global Compact|Global Compact]] in Sri Lanka.{{cite web |title= UNGC Participants and Stakeholders |url= http://www.unglobalcompact.org/participants/search?commit=t&country%5B%5D=111&page=1&per_page=250|accessdate=11 October 2012}} ==History== [[File:Patrick G. Spence.jpg|thumb|Patrick G. Spence]] Whilst the roots of Aitken Spence can be dated back to Wilson & Archer Partnership of the 1830s in the early [[British Ceylon|British Colonial Ceylon]], the company began to take its current form after the signing of a formal partnership agreement between Thomas Clark and Patrick Gordon Spence—Scottish merchants and shipping agents{{cite book | last = Wright | first = Arnold |title= Twentieth Century Impressions of Ceylon: Its History, People, Commerce.. |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=eUF_rS8FEoIC&pg=PA437 |accessdate=8 May 2012}} in [[Galle]]—on 1 September 1868, wherein Clark Spence & Co. was established.{{cite web | last = Aitken Spence| year = 2011| title= Aitken Spence Company Annual Report 2010-2011: Time Line |pages = 182–183 | url = http://www.aitkenspence.com/pdf/ar2011/aitken_spence_company_annual_report_2010_2011.pdf | accessdate=17 January 2012}}{{cite news | title = The Rootage of Insurance in Sri Lanka | author = M.Z.M. Nazim | newspaper = The Island | location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 17 November 2009 | url = http://www.island.lk/2009/11/17/business8.html | accessdate=17 November 2011}} Clark Spence & Co.'s trading segment at this stage included exports of [[graphite|natural vein graphite]] (plumbago), gems, hides, [[Caesalpinia sappan|Sappan wood]], [[ebony]], coffee, coconut oil, [[coir|coir yarn, bristle fibre]], arrack, and [[citronella oil]] to [[United Kingdom]], [[Continental Europe]], [[United States of America]] and [[Australia]]; and imports of [[Burma|Burmese]] rice and coal for [[Steamboat|steamer ship]] [[Fuel oil#Bunker fuel|bunkers]].{{cite web | last = Aitken Spence| year = 2005| title= Aitken Spence Company Annual Report 2004-2005: A Brief Historical Outlook |pages = 126/128 | url = http://www.aitkenspence.com/pdf/aitken_spence_2004_05_annual%20_report.pdf| accessdate=17 January 2012}} On 5 April 1871, Patrick Gordon Spence, secured Clark Spence & Co. as the sole agent of Lloyd's of London in [[Ceylon]]. In order to service the Agency for the [[Lloyd's|Lloyd's of London]] for the [[Port of Colombo]], Clark Spence & Co. partnered with Britton, Aitken & Co. to open a branch office in [[Colombo]]. On New Year's Day, 1873, E.C. Britton opted out of the Britton, Aitken & Co. partnership, resulting in Patrick Gordon Spence, Edward Aitken and S.R. Aitken coming together to form Aitken Spence & Co. to manage the operations in Colombo, whilst Clark Spence & Co. continued in partnership to operate in Galle. In 1876, Aitken Spence & Co. obtained the Lloyds agency from Clark Spence & Co. Aitken Spence had also obtained the local agency of [[Morgan Crucible| Morgan Crucible Company]] for trading in plumbago. As Colombo became the commercial capital of Sri Lanka, Aitken Spence & Co became more prominent and subsequently its partner company, Clark Spence & Co. originally based in Galle, became a subsidiary of Aitken Spence & Co.{{cite web | last = Lanka Monthly Digest (LMD)| year = 2013| title= Corporate Heritage: Aitken Spence | url = http://lmd.lk/2013/12/26/corporate-heritage-profiles-9/| accessdate=15 April 2014}} [[File:Edward Aitken.jpg|thumb|Edward Aitken]] By the 1880s, Aitken Spence had also secured the shipping agencies [[:nl:Koninklijke Rotterdamsche Lloyd|Koninklijke Rotterdamsche Lloyd]] and [[Netherland Line|Stoomvaart Maatschappij Nederland]] for Ceylon.{{cite web | last = Lorck| year = 1912| title= Isles of the East: An Illustrated Guide. | url = https://archive.org/stream/cu31924010584682/cu31924010584682_djvu.txt| accessdate=23 December 2012}} The company moved into plantations sector as an agency house in the early 1900s and with the onset of the Great Depression, began to withdraw from its trading business. In 1918, Aitken Spence purchased the Freudenberg Building in Colombo, and made it its company headquarters having renamed the building as Lloyds Building. As a pioneer in port operations, Aitken Spence was entrusted in coordinating the Operations of Colombo Port during the Second World War. Aitken Spence became a Private Company in 1952. In its centenary year, 1968, it appointed its first Sri Lankan Chairman, E.L. Van Langenberg.{{cite web | last = Aitken Spence|title= Our Heritage |url= http://www.aitkenspence.com/about_us/shipping_tourism_insurance_industry_sri_lanka.asp |accessdate=17 January 2012}} By 1971, as Sri Lanka was preparing to end British dominion and declare as [[Sri Lanka#Independence|republic]], the company became a wholly Sri Lankan owned entity.{{cite book | last = Shalini Perera | year = 2011| title= Corporate Ownership and Control | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=VXT36YV6RBIC&pg=PA124 | accessdate=15 May 2014}} In 1972, it began to offer shares to its executives, thereby broad basing its ownership. The company eventually moved on from this model and in 1983 offered its shares to the general public on the [[Colombo Stock Exchange]] with an issued share capital of Rs. 51 million.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence Historic Milestones | newspaper = LMD | location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = September 2005 | url = http://lmd.lk/archives/2005/September/cov7.htm | accessdate=12 October 2012}} During the early 1960s and early 1970s, Insurance and Plantations sectors—which were core business segments of Aitken Spence, where the company had been well established at the time—were nationalized.{{cite news |title= Changing of the guard at Aitken Spence|url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/011230/bus3.html|newspaper= The Sunday Times |date= 30 December 2001|accessdate= 5 April 2014}}{{cite news |title= R. Sivaratnam retires after 40 years at Aitken Spence|url= http://www.priu.gov.lk/news_update/features/20020103sivaratnam_retires.htm|newspaper= Daily News |date= 1 January 2002|accessdate= 12 November 2015}} However, the Group's [[marine insurance]] segment (including its Lloyd Agency) continued to operate as it did not fall within the purview of nationalization. Despite the setbacks from nationalization, in realizing the then government's thrust to boost tourism, Aitken Spence launched its tourism segment in 1972 with investments in its first hotel (Neptune Hotel in Beruwala, Sri Lanka opened in 1974). The company then entered into Aviation in 1974 (as general sales agent for [[Singapore Airlines]] in Sri Lanka). In consolidating its travel agency business that had begun with the launch of Aitken Spence Hotels in 1974, Aitken Spence set up Aitken Spence Travels in 1977 as inbound and outbound tour operators in Sri Lanka and as agents for [[Eurail]] and Britrail.{{cite news |title= Prema Cooray : A long and colourful journey|url= http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2002/12/15/bus17.html|newspaper= The Sunday Observer |date= 15 December 2002|accessdate= 15 May 2014}} Tourism is now a core business segment of Aitken Spence. With Sri Lanka adopting open market economic policies focused on export led growth in 1977, Aitken Spence forayed further into new business segments : Container and allied services in 1979; Garments and apparels in 1979;{{cite web |url= http://www.aitkenspence.com/strategic_investments/garment_manufacture_in_sri_lanka.asp |title= Garment Manufacture|accessdate= October 9, 2012}} International courier service agency with [[TNT N.V.|TNT]] in 1981; and Elevators in 1989 as agent of [[Otis Elevator Company|OTIS]]. With insurance sector being deregulated in the 1980s, the Group played a pivotal role in the resurgence of private sector insuarance as a proponent of the National Insurance Corporation and Union Assuarance Ltd, stakes in which Aitken Spence subsequently divested. Aitken Spence reentered Plantations sector, when the sector was reprivatized in 1992, through its stake in Udapussellawa Plantation PLC that was later divested. In response to the Power Crisis in Sri Lanka in 1996, Aitken Spence began to explore investment opportunities in power generation sector, with first two power plants coming online in 2002.{{cite news |title= CEB grid to get 20 mega watt boost |url= http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2002/03/10/bus01.html |newspaper= The Sunday Observer |date= 10 March 2002 |accessdate= 9 October 2012 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150924111719/http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2002/03/10/bus01.html |archive-date= 24 September 2015 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }} The Group also maintained container vessel operations, with acquisition of five ships in a joint venture with Ceyline Group in 2003, which it later divested in 2008. In 2010, in continuing its partnership with Ceyline Group, Aitken Spence invested in [[Colombo International Nautical and Engineering College|CINEC]], Sri Lanka's largest private higher education institution. In 2004, Aitken Spence Travels partnered with [[TUI Group]] of Germany to form a joint venture that is the largest leisure, travel and tourism company in the world. Aitken Spence was the first Sri Lankan resort operator to embark on overseas resort operations having acquired Bathala Island Resort of [[Maldives]] in 1993.{{cite news |title= Kandalama, Club Rannhali my indelible moments|url= http://www.island.lk/index.php?page_cat=article-details&page=article-details&code_title=62856|newspaper= The Island |date= 2 October 2012|accessdate= 15 May 2014}} In 1996, Aitken Spence entered [[Bangladesh]] through Aitken Spence Cargo with its shipping services.{{cite web | last = Aitken Spence Cargo| title= About Ace Cargo |url= http://www.acecargo.lk/about-acecargo.html|accessdate=17 January 2012 }} A decade later, in 2006, Aitken Spence entered the Indian hospitality sector, having secured management contracts for five hotel properties in [[India]]. On the same year, the company broke new ground by becoming the first Sri Lankan company to venture into port efficiency management outside of Sri Lanka, when it undertook to improve efficiency of ports in the African continent.{{cite news |title= Sri Lanka Aitken Spence to make Mozambique port efficient |url=http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/fullstory.php?nid=1702158326 |newspaper= Lanka Business Online |date= 12 June 2011 |accessdate=21 March 2012}} The company increased its global presence even further by obtaining the management of four hotel properties in [[Oman]] in 2007. In 2013, Aitken Spence announced its proposed venture into [[Fiji]] to manage the Ports of [[Suva]] and [[Lautoka]] in a public private partnership with the Government of Fiji.{{cite news |title= Aitken Spence PLC takes over the management of two major ports in Fiji |url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/130505/business-times/aitken-spence-plc-takes-over-the-management-of-two-major-ports-in-fiji-42782.html |newspaper= The Sunday Times |date= 5 May 2013 |accessdate=6 May 2013}} The Group has expressed interest to further diversify its investments in Fiji, venturing into hospitality, power and printing sectors.{{cite news |title= Company plans for more investment in Fiji |url=http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=293963 |newspaper= The Fiji Times Online |date= 4 February 2015 |accessdate=7 February 2015}} Currently, the company has operations in eight countries (Sri Lanka, Maldives, Bangladesh, India, South Africa, Oman, Fiji and Myanmar), spanning several continents{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Company Annual Report 2017-2018:Our Network |pages = 8, 28–33 | url = http://aitkenspence.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Aitken-Spence-PLC-AR-2017-18.pdf | accessdate=15 June 2018}} with 13,000 employees.{{cite video |people= |year= 2018 |title= Corporate Video|url= http://www.aitkenspence.com/about_us/hotels_logistics_power_sri_lanka.asp |language= |publisher= Aitken Spence|accessdate=21 March 2012|time= }}{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Annual Report Key Events 2017/2018|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=18 June 2018 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/annualreport/#KeyEvents}} == Governance structure == Aitken Spence is governed by the chairman and the board of directors and is managed by the Group Management Committee.{{cite web | last = Aitken Spence| year = 2018| title= Aitken Spence Company Annual Report 2017-2018: Board of Directors and Board of Management | url = http://aitkenspence.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Aitken-Spence-PLC-AR-2017-18.pdf | accessdate=15 June 2018}} === Chairman and Board of Directors === The current chairman of Aitken Spence is [[Harry Jayawardena|Mr. Harry Jayawardena]]. He is the founder director and current chairman/managing director of the Stassen Group of Companies – a diversified group in exports and import trade, the chairman of Lanka Milk Foods (CWE) PLC, Browns Beach Hotels PLC, Balangoda Plantations PLC, Madulsima Plantations PLC, Melstacorp PLC, Ambewela Livestock Company Ltd, Lanka Bell Ltd and also the current chairman of the [[Distilleries Company of Sri Lanka|Distilleries Company of Sri Lanka (DCSL) PLC]]. The current panel of board directors includes Mr. Rajan Brito, deputy chairman/managing director; and executive directors Dr. Rohan Fernando, and Ms. Stasshani Jayawardena; and the non-executive directors Mr. G.C. Wickremasinghe, Mr. Charles Gomez, Mr. Niranjan Deva Aditya and Mr. Rajan Asirwatham.{{cite web |title= Stasshani Jayawardena Appointed to the Aitken Spence PLC Board |url= http://aitkenspenceplc.wordpress.com// |date= 29 November 2013 |accessdate=30 November 2013}} [[File:Aitken Spence Towers.JPG|thumb|x200px|Aitken Spence Towers, Corporate Headquarters of Aitken Spence Group, in Colombo. 02.]] === Group Management Committee === Group Management Committee is headed by Mr. Rajan Brito. The other members of the Group Management Committee are Dr. Rohan Fernando, Ms. Stasshani Jayawardena, Ms. Nilanthi Sivapragasam, Mr. Rohan Pandithakorralage, Ms. Nimmi Guneratne, Mr. Susith Jayawickrama, Mr. Dinesh Mendis, Mr. Prasanna Karunathilake, Mr. Leel Wickremarachchi, Mr. Nalin Jayasundera, Mr. Ranil De Silva, Mr. Keethi Jayaweera (resigned w.e.f. 31.03.2018), Mr. Iqram Cuttilan, Mr. Janaka Gunawardena, Mr. Surendar Mariappan, Mr. Jerome Brohier and Mr. Channa Gunawardana.{{cite web | last = Aitken Spence| year = 2014| title= Aitken Spence Company Annual Report 2017-2018 | url = http://aitkenspence.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Aitken-Spence-PLC-AR-2017-18.pdf | accessdate=15 June 2018}} ==Corporate sustainability== Aitken Spence PLC was adjudged the winner of the Best Corporate Citizen Sustainability Award 2017 conducted by the [[Ceylon Chamber of Commerce]]. The company has been ranked among the Top 10 Corporate Citizens for an unprecedented 12 consecutive years.{{cite news |url= http://www.ft.lk/front-page/Aitken-Spence-wins--Best-Corporate-Citizen-Sustainability-Award-2017-/44-644258|title= Best Corporate Citizen Sustainability Award |date= 29 November 2017|accessdate=15 June 2018}} Aitken Spence PLC won two category awards for Employee Relations and Community Relations, Triple Bottom Line Award for its work on Environmental Sustainability and was awarded the sector based sustainability champions for Diversified Holdings.{{cite news |title=Best Corporate Citizen Award |newspaper=The Island |date=29 November 2017 |accessdate=7 February 2018 |url= http://www.island.lk/index.php?page_cat=article-details&page=article-details&code_title=175776}} Aitken Spence's sustainability framework has been rated Platinum by STING Corporate Accountability Index 2018 for the 6th consecutive year and has been ranked among the top three companies in the index since 2011.{{cite news |title=Aitken Spence Rated Platinum |newspaper=Daily News |date=21 March 2018 |accessdate=26 March 2018 |url= http://www.dailynews.lk/2018/03/21/business/146074/aitken-spence-rated-platinum-consecutively-corporate-accountability}} Published by LMD bi-annually, the index rated the top 50 companies from the LMD 100 (excluding investment companies) as well as key state-owned enterprises on a holistic and integrated model covering corporate responsibility, sustainability and governance. STING Consultants recognized Aitken Spence's Integrated Sustainability Policy as ‘Best in Class for Policy Coverage’ in 2011 and 2012.{{cite news |url= http://lmd.lk/2012/02/01/sting-corporate-accountability-index-methodology/|title= STING CORPORATE ACCOUNTABILITY INDEX METHODOLOGY|date= 1 February 2012|accessdate=15 October 2012}} STING Consultants have also recognized Aitken Spence's Integrated Sustainability Policy{{cite web |url= http://www.aitkenspence.com/sustainability/sustainability_approach.asp |title= Sustainability: Our Approach |accessdate=13 October 2012}}{{cite web |url= http://www.aitkenspence.com/pdf/as_integrated_sustainability_policy_english.pdf|title= Integrated Sustainability Policy |accessdate=13 October 2012}} as ‘Best in Class for Policy Coverage’ in 2011 and 2012.{{cite news |url= http://www.ft.lk/2012/02/27/sting-recognises-aitken-spence-sustainability-strategy/|title= STING recognises Aitken Spence Sustainability Strategy |date= 27 February 2012|accessdate=13 October 2012}}{{cite news |url= http://www.ft.lk/2011/06/17/aitken-spence-integrated-sustainability-for-long-term-value/|title= Aitken Spence: Integrated sustainability for long-term value |date= 17 June 2011|accessdate=13 October 2012}} In 2012, Aitken Spence was adjudged the Winner of the Best Corporate Citizen Award 2012 conducted by the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce. The Group was also recognized with sector awards in Economic & Governance sector and Environment sector during that year in addition to being credited with the category award for best Financial Performance.{{cite news |url= http://www.dailymirror.lk/business/other/23439-aitken-spence-bags-best-corporate-citizen-award-2012-.html|title= Aitken Spence bags Best Corporate Citizen Award 2012 | date= 13 November 2012 |accessdate=27 November 2012}} In 2013 and 2014, Aitken Spence was recognized as the second runner-up of the Best Corporate Citizen Sustainability Awards and was also recognized as the category winner for environmental management (in 2013) and environmental integration (2014).{{cite news |url= http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/news/sri-lankas-chamber-recognizes-corporate-citizenship/312684159|title= Sri Lanka's Chamber recognizes corporate good works | date= 27 November 2013 |accessdate=27 November 2013}}{{cite news |url= http://www.ft.lk/2014/11/26/mas-intimate-wins-coveted-best-corporate-citizen-sustainability-award-2014/|title= MAS Intimate wins coveted Best Corporate Citizen Sustainability Award 2014 | date= 26 November 2014 |accessdate=26 November 2014}} As a result of the company's long-standing engagement with the local network of the [[United Nations Global Compact|UN Global Compact]], Aitken Spence has been admitted to the board and the steering committee of the Sri Lanka Network.{{cite web |url= https://aitkenspenceplc.wordpress.com/2011/11/ |title= Aitken Spence Recognized as a Best Corporate Citizen for the Sixth Year Running |accessdate=13 October 2012}} The company reports 'Advanced’ in the UNGC Communication on Progress (COP) which indicates that the company qualifies as GC Active and, in addition, cover the company's implementation of advanced criteria and best practices.{{cite web |url= https://www.unglobalcompact.org/participation/report/cop/ |title= The Communication on Progress (COP) in Brief |accessdate=8 June 2018}}{{cite web |url= https://www.unglobalcompact.org/participation/report/cop/create-and-submit/advanced?page=1&per_page=250/ |title= Total number of GC Advanced COPs received |accessdate=8 June 2018}} Dr. Rohan Fernando, head of plantations and business development at Aitken Spence, was the former chairman of the Global Compact Sri Lanka Network.{{cite news |url= http://www.dailynews.lk/2011/05/16/bus18.asp|title= Environmental trusteeship essential for sustainability |date= 16 May 2011|accessdate=13 October 2012}} Aitken Spence is amongst the first 38 companies in the world to endorse the Women's Empowerment Principles, a joint initiative of [[UN Women]] and UN Global Compact to promote gender equality in business, and the first company to do so in Sri Lanka.{{cite web |url= http://www.dailynews.lk/2010/06/22/bus04.asp|title= Aitken Spence signs UN's Women's Empowerment Principles | date = 22 June 2010 |accessdate=13 October 2012}}{{cite web |url= http://weprinciples.org/Site/CeosSpeak/ |title= CEOs Speak |accessdate=13 October 2012}} Aitken Spence is also one of the first companies in Sri Lanka to pledge its support to the Caring for Climate initiative, which is a joint effort by [[UNEP]], [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]] and [[United Nations Global Compact|UNGC]] to promote positive climate action in business.{{cite web |url= http://www.unglobalcompact.org/docs/news_events/8.1/caring_for_climate.pdf |title= Caring for Climate: The Business Leadership Platform| date = June 2010 |accessdate=13 October 2012}}{{cite web| url=http://www.caringforclimate.org/about-list.php |title= Caring for Climate: List of Signatories}} In July 2013, Aitken Spence launched '''Empowering Sri Lanka First''', an English and IT teaching program for children from its neighbouring communities as its flagship corporate community engagement initiative. The program enrols eight-year-old students for weekend English classes (180 children currently enrolled in pilot phase from Dambulla, Ahungalla, and Mawaramandiya) for a period of three years. The curriculum of the English program has been custom designed by [[British Council]] to complement Sri Lanka's local school syllabus and teachers from local communities trained on interactive [[pedagogy]]. Aitken Spence has announced its plans to commence the IT component of the program in September 2013.{{cite news |title= Aitken Spence launches ‘Empowering Sri Lanka First’|url= http://www.ft.lk/2013/07/27/aitken-spence-launches-empowering-sri-lanka-first/ | date= 27 July 2013 |accessdate=4 August 2013}} The project was recognized with a merit award at the Best Sustainability Projects Awards 2014. As part of a broadbased diversification strategy, the sector embarked on a landmark project in the country's waste to energy sphere. Seen as a vital and much needed solution for the waste disposal crisis within Colombo city limits, the proposed project involves the construction of a 10MW waste-toenergy plant at Muthurajawela. The plant will be fuelled by waste collected from the Colombo Municipal Area, which was previously dumped in Meethotamulla. The plant is equipped to convert between 600 – 800 metric tonnes of municipal solid waste daily to electricity.{{cite news |title= The first waste-to-energy initiative in Sri Lanka |url= http://www.ft.lk/article/634380/Two-waste-to-energy-plants-to-get-off-the-ground-today/ | date= 10 August 2017 |accessdate= 9 March 2018}}{{cite news |title= HNB partners up as lead banker to Sri hospitality sector in 1974, with the opening of Neptune Hotel—designed by [[Geoffrey Bawa|Deshamanya Geoffrey Bawa]]—in [[Beruwala]], Sri Lanka. In July 2011, the Group rebranded the hotel as Heritance Ayurveda Maha Gedara after a major renovation wherein the hotel was converted to an [[Ayurveda#Sri Lanka|Ayurveda]] wellness resort.{{cite news |title=Heritance Ayurveda Maha Gedara- opens |newspaper=Daily News |date=17 December 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2012 |url= http://www.dailynews.lk/2011/12/17/bus60.asp}} In 2017, Heritance Ayurveda Maha Gedara, was accoladed with the internationally recommended Travelife for Hotels and Accommodations Gold Certification for the hotel's commitment to sustainability and ethical business practices.{{cite news |title=Heritance Ayurveda Maha Gedara achieves Travelife Gold Certification |newspaper=Daily Mirror |date=12 October 2017 |accessdate=6 March 2018 |url= http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Heritance-Ayurveda-Maha-Gedara-achieves-Travelife-Gold-Certification-138274.html}} In 2018, Heritance Ayurveda Maha Gedara was recognized by [[:pl:FIT Reisen|FIT Reisen]], a leading provider of health and wellness travel, with the Quality Certificate in the category of ‘Ayurveda and yoga’.{{cite news |title=Heritance Ayurveda Maha Gedara recognised by Fit Reisen for quality |newspaper=Sri Lanka Travel News |date=27 March 2018 |accessdate=6 May 2018 |url= https://srilankatravelnews.wordpress.com/2018/03/27/heritance-ayurveda-maha-gedara-recognised-by-fit-reisen-for-quality/}} ===== Heritance Ahungalla ===== [[File:Heritance Kandalama Exterior View.JPG|thumb|x200px|Exterior view of Heritance Kandalama]] Heritance Ahungalla, formerly known as Triton, is Sri Lanka's first five-star beach resort—launched in 1981 in Ahungalla, a town in southern coastal belt of Sri Lanka. Originally designed by [[Geoffrey Bawa|Deshamanya Geoffrey Bawa]], the 152 roomed 5 star resort was relaunched under the Heritance brand in June 2006 subsequent to a US$13 million refurbishment.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Hotels Annual Report 2010/2011|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=6 March 2012 |url= http://www.aitkenspencehotels.com/images/homepage/141_aitken_spence_hotel_annual_report_2010_2011.pdf }} The hotel is the first hotel in Sri Lanka to receive the ISO 50001 certification for energy management.{{cite news |title= Heritance Ahungalla, first Sri Lankan hotel to be ISO50001 certified |newspaper= sundaytimes.lk |date= 25 December 2011|accessdate=28 March 2012|url= http://sundaytimes.lk/111225/BusinessTimes/bt38.html }} The five-star Heritance Ahungalla won the prestigious TUI Top Quality 2018. This was awarded from [[TUI Group]], the largest leisure, travel and tourism company in the world. ===== Heritance Kandalama ===== '''Heritance Kandalama''', the flagship hotel of Aitken Spence, is located in Kandalama, Dambulla in proximity to two [[World Heritage Site|UNESCO World Heritage Sites]]— [[Sigiriya]] and [[Dambulla Cave Temple]]. The hotel is built into a natural rock outcrop within a jungle setting and overlooks the [[Kandalama Reservoir]]. Designed by [[Geoffrey Bawa|Deshamanya Geoffrey Bawa]],{{cite news|title= Infinite relaxation in Sri Lanka’s cultural triangle|author= |newspaper= Daily FT |date= 4 February 2012|accessdate=28 March 2012|url= http://www.ft.lk/2012/02/04/infinite-relaxation-in-sri-lankas-cultural-triangle/}} it is the first hotel outside the United States to receive [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED certified]].{{cite news|title= Heritance crowned most energy efficient hotel chain by bagging Gold, Silver and Bronze Awards |author= |newspaper= Daily FT |date= 15 August 2011|accessdate=28 March 2012|url= http://www.ft.lk/2011/08/15/heritance-crowned-most-energy-efficient-hotel-chain-by-bagging-gold-silver-and-bronze-awards/}} The hotel was also the first in Asia to be Green Globe certified for its ecotourism best practices.{{cite news|title= Heritance Kandalama wins EarthCheck Silver certification |author= |newspaper= Daily News |date= 4 February ==== Aitken Spence School of Hospitality ==== Aitken Spence opened its School of Hospitality in November 2007 at Ahungalla, Sri Lanka with the assistance of the Austrian Chamber of Commerce and Hilfswerk to bridge the skills gap in the tourism sector. The school was initially set up to recover from the Tsunami and assist locals in the Ahungalle region. However, since the ending of the war, the school serves to assist the development in the North and the East as well as other rural areas in the country.{{cite news |title=Aitken Spence trains rural youth in Hospitality Sector |author= |url= http://sundaytimes.lk/100801/BusinessTimes/bt36.html|newspaper= Sunday Times |date= |accessdate=28 March 2012}} The school has so far provided training opportunities for marginalized youth from Uva, North Central, East and Northern provinces in food and beverage services.{{cite web |url= http://aitkenspenceplc.wordpress.com/2010/11/23/aitken-spence-school-of-hospitality-produces-third-batch-of-hospitality-trainees-from-the-east-and-uva/ |title= Aitken Spence School of Hospitality Produces Third Batch of Hospitality Trainees from the East and Uva |author= |date= 23 November 2010 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=28 March 2012}}{{cite web |url= http://www.undp.lk/SubPressReleases/Pages/detail.aspx?ItemID=39 |title= 30 youth complete the UNDP-Aitken Spence School of Hospitality supported training in the hospitality industry |author= |date= 31 May 2012 |work= |publisher= UNDP |accessdate=15 October 2012}} In 2015, 27 trainees having completed a 3-month basic course in food and beverage, graduated from the Aitken Spence School of Hospitality in Ahungalla.{{cite news |title=Twenty seven youth graduate from Aitken Spence School of Hospitality |author= |url= http://www.dailymirror.lk/65881/twenty-seven-youth-graduate-from-aitken-spence-school-of-hospitality|newspaper= Daily Mirror |date= |accessdate=10 March 2015}} === Maldives === Aitken Spence entered Maldivian hotel sector in 1993 with its investment in Bathala Island Resort. July 2015 under the brand Turyaa Chennai.{{cite web |url= https://www.cse.lk/cmt/upload_report_file/521_1433502972773.pdf |title= Aitken Spence Hotel Holdings PLC Annual Report 2014/2015 |accessdate=7 June 2015}} The 140-room property, Turyaa Chennai opened its doors on 1st October 2015 and is located in the IT Corridor of Chennai and just a short drive away from the heart of the city. The property obtained the “5-Star Deluxe” classification in 2017, ranking it as one of five hotels in Chennai to have obtained this highly sought after accreditation. In 2018, the property was awarded the 'best five-star deluxe hotel’ in Tamil Nadu at the Tamil Nadu Tourism Awards 2018.{{cite news |title= Aitken Spence Hotels Turyaa Chennai amongst Top Five-Star Hotels in the City |newspaper = LBO |accessdate= 15 June 2017 |url= http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/aitken-spence-hotels-turyaa-chennai-amongst-top-five-star-hotels-in-the-city/}}{{cite news |title= Aitken Spence’s Turyaa Chennai awarded best five-star deluxe in Tamil Nadu |newspaper = Daily FT |accessdate= 8 May 2018 |url= http://www.ft.lk/travel-tourism/Aitken-Spence-s-Turyaa-Chennai-awarded-best-five-star-deluxe-in-Tamil-Nadu/27-654025}} === Oman === In Oman, Aitken Spence currently owns one hotel and manages five hotels:{{cite news | title = Sri Lanka Spence Hotel mulls more properties in Oman | newspaper = economynext| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 12 June 2015 | url = http://www.economynext.com/Sri_Lanka_Spence_Hotel_mulls_more_properties_in_Oman-3-2062.html |accessdate=11 August 2015}} ==== Al Falaj Hotel Muscat ==== Al Falaj Hotel is a 140 roomed 4 star resort located in the city of [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]]. Aitken Spence bought the hotel from Oman Hotels and Tourism Company for whom the company had been managing the property since 2008.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence’s RO14mn offer for Al Falaj approved | newspaper = Muscat Daily| location = Muscat, Oman | date = 25 January 2016 | url = http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Business/Aitken-Spence-s-RO14mn-offer-for-Al-Falaj-approved-4kiq |accessdate=8 February 2016}} ==== Al Wadi Hotel, Sohar ==== Al Wadi Hotel is a 79-room 3 star resort in [[Sohar]]. ==== Desert Nights Camp, Al Wasil ==== Desert Nights Camp is a 5 star tented resort property with 30 luxurious Bedouin style tents located in Al Wasil, a township close to Muscat. ==== Ruwi Hotel, Muscat ==== Located in close proximity to Seeb International Airport, Ruwi Hotel is a 3 star hotel with a room inventory of 100 rooms. ==== Sur Plaza Hotel, Sur ==== Sur Plaza Hotel is a 4 star 95 room resort located in [[Sur, Oman|Sur]] in proximity to Green Turtle Beach at Ras-al-Hadd. ==== Jabal Akhdar Hotel, Nizwa ==== Jabal Akhdar Hotel is a 26-room boutique hotel located in [[Nizwa]], 152 km from the Muscat International Airport.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence in US $ 25mn Indian hotel acquisition | newspaper = Daily Mirror| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 12 June 2014 | url = http://www.dailymirror.lk/business/features/48316-aitken-spence-in-us--25mn-indian-hotel-acquisition.html |accessdate=7 November 2014}} == Transport == [[File:Hapag Lloyd Container 01.jpg|thumb|x200px | Aitken Spence Logistics offers container shipping]] Aitken Spence offers integrated transportation services in air-sea freight forwarding, warehousing, distribution, couriers, ground transport and marine. Its services cover the complete physical cargo flow process from shipper to recipient. It also handles third and fourth party logistics management contracts.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Logistic Solutions|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=10 August 2012 |url= http://www.aitkenspence.com/logistic_solutions/logistic_solutions_provider_sri_lanka.asp}} The company also represents [[DB Schenker]] in Sri Lanka and Maldives.{{cite web |title= DB Schenker announces new forwarding partner in Sri Lanka|author= Lloyds Loading List |accessdate=28 October 2015 |url= http://www.lloydsloadinglist.com/freight-directory/news/DB-Schenker-announces-new-forwarding-partner-in-Sri-Lanka/64608.htm#.VjEHfcUrJdi}} Also, represents [[DPD Group]] and [[DTDC]] Express in Sri Lanka and Maldives.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence partners DPD Group for courier services. |author= Daily News|accessdate=14 March 2017 |url= http://www.dailynews.lk/2017/03/14/business/110317/aitken-spence-partners-dpd-group-courier-services}}{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence partners with Europe’s second largest int’l parcel delivery network. |author= Mirror Business |accessdate=16 March 2017 |url= http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Aitken-Spence-partners-with-Europe-s-second-largest-int-l-parcel-delivery-network--125591.html}} The segment represents the cargo GSA for Qatar airways in Sri Lanka and the cargo GSA for Sri Lankan Airlines in Maldives and Myanmar, and are the managing agents for cargo GSA for Sri Lankan Airlines in Bangladesh.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence hosts WACO International Conference in Colombo. |author= Lanka Business Online |accessdate=4 December 2015 |url= http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/aitken-spence-hosts-waco-international-conference-in-colombo/}} === Cargo consolidation and storage facilities === In terms of cargo consolidation, the company offers both local and multi country cargo consolidation. In Sri Lanka, it operates its own container freight station with in-house customs that complies with [[Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism|C-TPAT]] standards. Aitken Spence Cargo and Courier services provide air freight, ocean freight, supply chain management, brokerage, project cargo management and international and domestic courier as primary services and also specialize in airline cargo GSA representation [http://aitkenspence.com/logistics-2/cargo-courier-services/ Aitken Spence Logistics]. Aitken Spence Logistics also services shipments of garments through its garments on hanger facilities and quality assurance centre facilities. The company also offers refrigerated storage services in terms of cold rooms and [[Refrigerated container|reefer]] containers to its clients. With respect to warehousing facilities in Sri Lanka, Aitken Spence operates a central cargo storage complexses with a total floor area exceeding 300,000 sqft, located in Colombo, Wattala, Mabole and Katunayake Zone with a modern fleet of equipment and cargo handling machinery.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Annual Report Logistics 2017/2018|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=10 July 2018 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/annualreport/}}{{cite news |title=Aitken Spence Logistics enhanced by world class equipment |newspaper=Sunday Times |accessdate=4 March 2018 |url= http://www.sundaytimes.lk/180304/business-times/aitken-spence-logistics-enhanced-by-world-class-equipment-283896.html}} === Container handling, repair and modification facilities === The container services arm of Aitken Spence Logistics that processes a container every two minutes is the first company in Sri Lanka to operate its own container depot (first at Mattakkuliya in 1979 and shifted to Mabole in 1989).{{cite web |title= Reliably Consolidated|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=10 August 2012 |url= http://aitkenspenceplc.wordpress.com/tag/mattakuliya/}} In addition, Aitken Spence also runs a Lloyd's approved facility for container modification and repair services.{{cite news |title=Aitken Spence Logistics opens new Container Repair and Rigging Facility |newspaper=Sunday Times |date=1 June 2014 |accessdate=3 July 2018 |url= http://www.sundaytimes.lk/140601/business-times/aitken-spence-logistics-opens-new-container-repair-and-rigging-facility-100546.html}} The company provides import and export container handling services, handling transshipment cargo, and the servicing of passenger cruise vessels, car carriers and casual callers.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Annual Report 2017/2018|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=18 June 2018 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/annualreport/}}{{cite news |title=Aitken Spence Logistics pursues continuous fleet enhancement |newspaper=Daily News |date=2 March 2018 |accessdate=30 May 2018 |url= http://www.dailynews.lk/2018/03/02/business/144345/aitken-spence-logistics-pursues-continuous-fleet-enhancementy}} === Ground transport and project cargo handling === Aitken Spence also offers transportation through its transport fleet of prime movers with 20’/40’ trailers, lorries and tank trucks. The Group is also capable in handling Heavy Over-Dimensional Project cargo. It is also the agent for Flexi Tank Services in Sri Lanka for Trans Ocean Distribution. === Freight forwarding, courier services and air cargo === [[File:Stern of the Colombo Express.jpg|thumb|x200px|Hapag Lloyd is represented in Sri Lanka through Aitken Spence Maritime]] In addition to its own haulage, Aitken Spence also provides freight forwarding through its global partner network. Aitken Spence Cargo, specialized freight-forwarding arm of Aitken Spence, provides air freight, sea freight, brokerage, customs facilitation and supply chain [[solution]]s to clients in Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Maldives. Aitken Spence handles cargo sales agencies for [[Singapore Airlines Cargo]], [[Livingston Energy Flight|Livingston Air]], [[Air Jamaica]], [[Air Italy]], [[Thomas Cook Airlines Scandinavia|My Travels]], [[Qatar Airways Cargo]] and [[EVA Air]] in Sri Lanka. It is also the General Sales Agents (Cargo) for My Travels in Maldives & Bangladesh; Livingston Air in Bangladesh, Singapore and Thailand; [[Continental Airlines Cargo]] in Bangladesh, while being the cargo sales agents for Livingston Air and [[SriLankan Airlines#Cargo|SriLankan Airlines Cargo]] in the Maldives. Aitken Spence Group represents [[TNT Express]] courier services in Sri Lanka and provides both domestic and international courier services. It also represents Spring Global Mail in Sri Lanka. === Maritime services === Aitken Spence offers services in the maritime sector through its maritime wing, Aitken Spence Maritime. Its services include liner agency representation(of G6 Alliance), cruise vessel representation, feeder and casual caller representation, break bulk facilities, and ship servicing and facilitation (crew services, bunkering, repairs, supply of provisions) for ports in Sri Lanka. It also provides ship chartering services. In January 2005, in a joint venture with Ceyline Holdings, Aitken Spence re-entered the ship owning for time charter business in order to profit from the then shipping boom.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence to invest $ 7.5 million on two vessels. |author= Daily News|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.dailynews.lk/2004/12/09/bus02.html}}{{cite web |title= Spence to double fleet to 10 ships. |author= Sunday Times|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.sundaytimes.lk/050626/ft/2.html}} In 2007, with the saturation of the ship chartering market, Aitken Spence exited the ship owning business and shifted its strategic focus to expanding its port management business. {{cite web |title= Sri Lanka conglomerate sells off ships |author= Lanka Business Online |accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/news/Sri_Lanka_conglomerate_sells_off_ships/424491405}}{{cite web |title= Sri Lanka's Aitken Spence hunts port management business |author= Lanka Business Online|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/news/Sri_Lankas_Aitken_Spence_hunts_port_management_business/1347781965}} In 2007, Aitken Spence in partnership with [[PSA International|Port of Singapore Authority]] submitted a joint bid to build and operate the South Container Terminal of the [[Colombo Harbor#Expansion project|Colombo Port Expansion Project]]. When the initial bidding process of [[Sri Lanka Port Authority]] (SLPA) stalled and was reactivated, Aitken Spence partnered with [[China Merchants Holdings (International)|China Merchant Holdings International]] and was the sole bidder in support of the project.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence port bid in our national interest |author= The Sunday Times|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.sundaytimes.lk/080302/FinancialTimes/ft334.html}}{{cite web |title= A wise call on Colombo South Port |author= The Sunday Times|accessdate=8 December 2013 |url= http://www.sundaytimes.lk/090830/FinancialTimes/ft39.html}} In 2010, the bid was approved by SLPA and construction began on the US$450 million project.{{cite web |title= Sri Lanka awards Rs. 50 bn Colombo South Port deal to China Holdings - Aitken Spence consortium |author= Asian Tribune |accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.asiantribune.com/news/2010/09/17/sri-lanka-awards-rs-50-bn-colombo-south-port-deal-china-holdings-aitken-spence-conso}}{{cite web |title= Deal signed to build Colombo Port Expansion project’s South Container Terminal|author= Daily FT|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.ft.lk/2011/11/14/deal-signed-to-build-colombo-port-expansion-project%E2%80%99s-south-container-terminal/}} However, in 2012, citing cost escalations and changes in financing requirements, Aitken Spence sold its stake to CMHI in 2012, realizing a LKR Rs. 630 million capital gain.{{cite web |title= Sri Lanka conglomerate sells stake on Colombo Port project for Rs. 630 million|author= Lanka Newspapers|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.lankanewspapers.com/news/2012/1/74081.html}}{{cite news |title= Sri Lanka's Aitken Spence sells port stake to China Merchants |author= Reuters|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/01/23/srilanka-port-spence-idUKL4E8CN4PO20120123 |date=23 January 2012}} Aitken Spence is the first Sri Lankan company to venture into port efficiency improvement, training and container terminal management overseas with its operations in the African continent. As a result of the strategic partnership with the Port of Durban from 2006, Aitken Spence won a "ship planning and mentoring" project covering the Ports of Durban, Cape Town and Ngqura in South Africa in 2010. In 2011, Aitken Spence announced that it has won a deal to improve the efficiency of Port of Nacala in Mozambique.{{cite web |title= Sri Lanka Aitken Spence to make Mozambique port efficient. |author= Lanka Business Online|accessdate=10 August 2012 |url= http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/fullstory.php?nid=1702158326}} In 2013, Aitken Spence took over the management of two Fijian ports, [[Suva]] and [[Lautoka]], with its purchase of 51% of Fiji Ports Terminal Ltd, a 100% owned subsidiary of Fiji Ports Corporation Ltd.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence aims to get port efficiency, productivity. |author= Fiji Sun|accessdate=4 August 2013 |url= http://www.fijisun.com.fj/2013/08/01/aitken-spence-aims-to-get-port-efficiency-productivity/}} The company further consolidated its presence in the Fijian maritime sector in acquiring a 20% stake in Fiji Ports Corporation Ltd. in November 2015.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence buys 20% stake in Fiji Ports Corp for $ 16 m; expands footprint in South Pacific |author= Daily FT|accessdate=6 November 2015 |url= http://www.ft.lk/article/493071/Aitken-Spence-buys-20--stake-in-Fiji-Ports-Corp-for---16-m--expands-footprint-in-South-Pacific}}{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence expands Fiji operations |author= Mirror Business|accessdate=6 November 2015 |url= http://www.dailymirror.lk/94255/aitken-spence-expands-fiji-operations}} In 2010, Aitken Spence renewed its alliance with Ceyline Group of Companies when it invested in [[CINEC|Colombo International Nautical and Engineering College (CINEC)]].{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence in strategic partnership with CINEC Maritime Campus. |author= The Nation|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.nation.lk/2010/04/11/busi5.htm}}{{cite web |title= Sri Lanka Aitken Spence mulls overseas maritime campus. |author= Lanka Business Online|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/news/sri-lanka-aitken-spence-mulls-overseas-maritime-campus/1064979551}} In 2012, Aitken Spence increased its stake in CINEC from 10% to 40% in a move to further strengthen its maritime portfolio.{{cite web |title= Sri Lanka Aitken Spence December net up 41-pct |author= Lanka Business Online|accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/news/Sri_Lanka_Aitken_Spence_December_net_up_41-pct/888547756}} Located in Malabe, the CINEC Campus is Sri Lanka's largest private higher education institution and also has branches in Colombo, Trincomalee and Jaffna. CINEC also manages the maritime academies in Fiji and Seychelles.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Annual Report 2017/2018|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=18 June 2018 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/annualreport/}} In 2013, further to Aitken Spence's entry into port management in Fiji, Fijian Government announced plans to invite CINEC to manage [[Fiji National University|Fiji National University's]] maritime school.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence boosts Fiji Port efficiencies by 35 pc in two months |author=Daily News |url=http://www.dailynews.lk/business/aitken-spence-boosts-fiji-port-efficiencies-35-pc-two-months#sthash.ENSNHQBs.dpuf |accessdate=15 December 2013}}{{cite web |title= 2014 Fiji National Budget Speech by PM Commodore Voreqe Bainimarama |author= Mai Life Magazine|accessdate=22 November 2013 |url= http://www.mailife.com.fj/2013/11/}}{{cite news |title=Cinec unveils ship shaped training 2017 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/services/}} === Destination management === [[File:SIA Boeing 747-400, 9V-SPF, SIN 5.jpg|thumb|x200px |Aitken Spence has represented Singapore Airlines in Sri Lanka General Sales Agent for [[Singapore Airlines|Singapore International Airlines]] in Sri Lanka and the Maldives. Aitken Spence is also the General Sales Agent for [[SriLankan Airlines]] in Maldives. === Financial services === In the financial services sector, Aitken Spence in a joint venture with Mercantile Merchant Bank, Sri Lanka offers [[Western Union|Western Union Money Transfer services]] in Sri Lanka with a network of over 2000 sub-agent locations countrywide, which includes banks, financial institutions and retail outlets. As an authorized agent for Western Union in Sri Lanka, the Group's money transfer services business has a commanding 65% share of the Western Union business in Sri Lanka.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Annual Report 2017/2018|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=11 July 2018 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/annualreport/}} Aitken Spence serves as survey and claim settling agents for [[Lloyd's of London]] since 1876, covering the commercial ports in Sri Lanka and the Republic of Maldives. It also carries out quality surveys and hull and machinery surveys. In addition, Aitken Spence Insurance also acts as survey and claims settling agents for several other reputed insurance companies worldwide including [[Aviva|AVIVA]], [[People's Insurance Company of China]], Oriental Insurance Co. of India, [[New India Assurance]], [[IFFCO Tokio General Insurance Company Limited|Iffco-Tokio]] of India, [[RSA Insurance Group|Royal & Sun Alliance Group]], Northern Marine Underwriters, China Pacific Property Insurance Co. Ltd, [[Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance Group|Sumitomo Fire & Marine Insurance Co. Ltd.]], [[Tokio Marine Nichido|Tokyo Marine & Fire Insurance Co.]] of Japan, Cesam of France, QBE Insurance of Singapore and [[American Home Assurance Company]] since 1949. === Knowledge and information technology === The Group also provides human resources consulting in Sri Lanka and overseas under brand "Genuity". Aitken Spence Technologies offers IT in, [[Enterprise Content Management]] (ECM), [[Enterprise Resource Planning]] (ERP), both based on core-[[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]] Applications and Technologies, and Application Development based on Open Source/Java technologies.{{cite web |title= Calspence Technologies consolidates and re-brands|author= FT Sri Lanka |accessdate=10 August 2012 |url= http://www.ft.lk/2012/02/23/calspence-technologies-consolidates-and-re-brands/}}{{cite web |title= Kia with Aitken Spence to deploy Oracle Solution to automate processes.|author= Lanka Business Today |accessdate=19 May 2015 |url= http://www.lankabusinesstoday.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9106:kia-with-aitken-spence-to-deploy-oracle-solution-to-automate-processes&catid=54:business&Itemid=76}} In 2012, Aitken Spence was appointed as [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]] University Education Re-seller Partner and Approved Training Centre.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Technologies appointed Oracle Uni approved re-seller partner, training centre.|author= FT Sri Lanka |accessdate=4 June 2013 |url= http://www.ft.lk/2012/03/03/aitken-spence-technologies-appointed-oracle-uni-approved-re-seller-partner-training-centre/}} Aitken Spence Technologies is also a member of [[IBM|IBM PartnerWorld]] program.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Technologies |accessdate=15 October 2013 |url= http://www.aitkenspencetech.com/}} In October 2013, '''PlantERM''', the Enterprise Resource Management application developed for the first time in Sri Lanka for the plantation sector by Aitken Spence Technologies, received the NBQSA Gold Award in the General Applications category.{{cite web |title= NBQSA 2013 Winners |accessdate=18 October 2013 |url= http://www.nbqsasrilanka.org/node/75/}} Aitken Spence offers financcial accounting outsourcing services through its subsidiary Aitken Spence Business Solutions in Sri Lanka, Maldives and Bangladesh. The business solutions partners include; Citi Bank, HSBC, Deutsche Bank and Standard Chartered Bank on the electronic banking and Oracle in the ERP solutions.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence to ride on BPO boom.|author= FT Sri Lanka |accessdate=10 August 2012 |url= http://www.ft.lk/2011/03/22/aitken-spence-to-ride-on-bpo-boom/}}{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Business Solutions |accessdate=15 October 2013 |url= http://www.spencebpo.com/3-services.html}}[https://aitkenspence.com/services/financial-accounting-outsourcing/ Aitken Spence Business Solutions] === Elevator agency === Aitken Spence also provides elevator services acting as the agent for [[Otis Elevator Company|OTIS]] Elevators (part of [[United Technologies Corporation]]) in Sri Lanka and Maldives since 1989. ==Strategic investments== ===Power generation=== Aitken Spence first entered the power sector in 1996 in a joint venture with a Japanese investor to build two thermal power plants in Sri Lanka with the Government of Sri Lanka inviting private sector to invest in resolving the then power crisis. However, due to the longevity of the process in obtaining clearances, the Japanese partner backed out and in 1999, Aitken Spence (51%) partnered with [[Commonwealth Development Corporation]] Globeleq (29%), Baneras House of India (10%) and [[Wartsila|Wartsila Finland Oy]] (10%) to construct the [[Ace Matara Power Station]] (24.4MW) and [[Ace Horana Power Station]] (24.4MW).{{cite news | title = HNB leads landmark financing deal of US$ 88 million | newspaper = The Sunday Leader| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 10 August 2003 | url = http://www.thesundayleader.lk/archive/20030810/business-3.htm| accessdate=9 October 2012}} Subsequently, following a Request for Proposal by [[Ceylon Electricity Board]] (CEB) in February 2002, Aitken Spence together with [[Caterpillar Inc.|Caterpillar Power Ventures Corporation]] began the construction of the [[Embilipitiya Power Station]] (100MW), which came online in April 2005.{{cite web |url= http://www.cat.com/cda/files/698809/7/CPGS_SriLanka.pdf |title= Ace Power Embilipitiya |accessdate=9 October 2012}} Ace Power Embilipitiya thermal power plant opeartes on a 100MW while the Branford Hydro power plant operates at 2.5MW, Ace Wind power plant at 3MW and Western Power at 10MW capacity. {{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Annual Report 2017/2018|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=10 July 2018 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/annualreport/}} The Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) between the [[Ceylon Electricity Board]] and Ace Power Embilipitiya lapsed in 2015; however, renewed the agreement for a one more year in April, 2016, when the country ran into power crisis after two back-to-back blackouts in late 2015 and early 2016. During the first quarter of 2018, the government decided to extend the purchasing of the thermal power for three more years as the country had four seasons of back-to-back dry spells, which exhausted reservoirs and the crucial catchment areas.{{cite web |url= http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Government-extends-agreement-with-Ace-Power-for-three-more-years-to-avert-power-crisis-148133.html |title= Government extends agreement with Ace Power for three more years to avert power crisis |newspaper = Mirror Business |accessdate=2 April 2018}} [[File:AitkenSpenceWindPower-Ambewela-September2012-1.jpg|thumb|x200px|Ace Wind Power, Ambewela]] ====Hydro, Wind, Solar, Waste-to-Energy and Dendro Power==== Aitken Spence has also sought to diversify its power portfolio with increased presence in the clean and renewable energy domain in Sri Lanka. Aitken Spence Power has already completed construction of the 2.5 MW '''Branford Hydro Power''' Plant in Matale, and of [[Ambewela Aitken Spence Wind Farm|Ace Wind Power]] power plant in [[Ambewela]]{{cite news|title=Blue chips eye more hydro, wind power plants |newspaper=Daily News |location=Colombo, Sri Lanka |date=8 June 2011 |url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2011/06/08/bus05.asp |accessdate=9 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823125438/http://www.dailynews.lk/2011/06/08/bus05.asp |archivedate=23 August 2011 }} that has an installed capacity of 3 MW. Both power plants were connected to the national grid during 2012/13 financial year.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence PLC Annual Report 2011/2012|author= Aitken Spence|accessdate=9 October 2012 |url= http://www.aitkenspence.com/pdf/ar2012/aitken_spence_plc_ar_2011_12_changed_1.pdf}} Aitken Spence Power is also currently building the [[Aitken Spence Power Station]], Waste-To-Energy Coprocessing Plant at Muthurajawela.{{cite news | title = Garbage Power At Rs. 22 A Unit| newspaper = The Sunday Leader| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 13 November 2011 | url = http://www.thesundayleader.lk/2011/11/13/garbage-power-at-rs-22-a-unit/| accessdate=9 October 2012}} Ace Power embarked on a landmark project in the country's waste to energy sphere. Seen as a vital and much needed solution for the waste disposal crisis within Colombo city limits, the proposed project involves the construction of a 10MW waste-toenergy plant at Muthurajawela. The plant will be fuelled by waste collected from the Colombo Municipal Area, which was previously dumped in Meethotamulla. The plant is equipped to convert between 600 – 800 metric tonnes of municipal solid waste daily to electricity. Estimated to cost Rs. 13 billion on completion, the project is funded through a combination of equity and term loan funding. The construction work on the project commenced following the ground-breaking ceremony held in August 2017 with the participation of H.E. the president. This new waste to energy project is due to commence commercial operations in 2019.{{cite news | title = Sri Lanka starts work on two 10MW waste-to-energy plants | newspaper = Economy Next | date = 10 August 2017 | url = http://www.economynext.com/Sri_Lanka_starts_work_on_two_10MW_waste_to_energy_plants-3-8486-.html}}{{cite news | title = HNB concludes Syndicated Term Loan for Sri Lanka’s first waste to energy plant | newspaper = Lanka Business Online | date = 31 May 2018 | url = http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/hnb-concludes-syndicated-term-loan-for-sri-lankas-first-waste-to-energy-plant/}} Aitken Spence Hotels (through biomass plants and solar generation){{cite news | title = Sri Lanka's Aitken Spence in renewable energy drive | newspaper = Lanka Business Online| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 5 October 2012 | url = http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/fullstory.php?nid=2104555452| accessdate=9 October 2012}} and Plantations (through mini hydro projects){{cite news | title = Elpitiya Plantations recognised for hydro power generation| newspaper = ft.lk| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 13 August 2012 | url = http://www.ft.lk/2012/08/13/elpitiya-plantations-recognised-for-hydro-power-generation/ | accessdate=9 October 2012}} have also undertaken mini power projects of their own. Heritance Ayurveda Maha Gedara is the first hotel in Sri Lanka to enter into a net metering agreement with CEB. Aitken Spence was the only Sri Lankan power sector Operations and Maintenance operator to have received ISO 9001, ISO 14001 and OHSAS 18001 certifications. The company has expressed its capacity to undertake operations and maintenance service contracts internationally. ===Plantation services=== [[File:Dunsinane Estate, Elpitiya Plantation.jpg|thumb|left| Dunsinane Estate, Nuwara Eliya]] Aitken Spence has been in the plantations industry from the early 1900s.{{cite web |url= http://www.superbrands.com/lkb1/pdf/aitkenspence.pdf |title= Aitken Spence|accessdate=9 October 2012}} In 1975, the estates originally owned by Aitken Spence were acquired under the plantation nationalization program. In 1992, with the re-privatization of plantations industry, Aitken Spence reentered the sector in taking over the management of Udapussellawa Plantation PLC. It also invested in a minority stake in Talawakelle Plantations. Aitken Spence later divested its stake in Udapussellawa and Talawakelle Plantations{{cite news | title = Talawakelle posts record profit and turnover| newspaper = The Island| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka| date = 2 April 2011 | url = http://www.island.lk/index.php?page_cat=article-details&page=article-details&code_title=22230| accessdate=9 October 2012}} The management of Elpitiya Plantations PLC was taken over by Aitken Spence in 1997 from Carsons through Aitken Spence Plantations Managements Ltd. The Group currently manages 13 estates (with over 8800 hectares of cultivated land) in Sri Lanka, producing high, mid and low grown teas.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Annual Report 2017/2018|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=5 June 2018 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/annualreport/}} From the 13 estates, six estates are located on the up cluster in [[Kandy]] and [[Nuwara Eliya]] districts (estates: Dunsinane, Sheen, Fernlands, Meddecombra, New Peacock and Nayapane) and seven estates in the low cluster (Deviturai, Talgaswella, Gulugahakanda, Lelwala, Ketandola, Bentota and Elpitiya). These estates conform with multiple standards on sustainability including ISO 22000 for food safety management system, [[Rainforest Alliance|Rainforest Alliance certification]], [[Ethical Tea Partnership]] and [[Forest Stewardship Council]] certification.{{cite news | title = Sri Lanka's New Peacock Estate claim highest yield among large tea farms| newspaper = economynext | location = Colombo, Sri Lanka| date = 22 April 2015 | url = http://www.economynext.com/Sri_Lanka_s_New_Peacock_Estate_claim_highest_yield_among_large_tea_farms-3-1586-9.html| accessdate=22 April 2015}} In addition to tea, Elpitiya Plantations also produces rubber, coconut, cinnamon and palm oil.{{cite web |url= http://aitkenspence.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Aitken-Spence-PLC-AR-2017-18.pdf |title= Annual Report Strategic Investments Plantations |accessdate=16 July 2018}} Group has diversified its plantation operations into other areas such as palm oil processing, hydro power development, speciality tea manufacturing and eco tourism.[http://www.elpitiya.com/ Elpitiya Plantations] The Group also has its own tea brand for black tea and green tea in Sri Lanka under the name "Harrow Ceylon Choice".[http://www.elpitiya.com/tea/ Elpitiya Tea] In January 2013, Elpitiya Plantations PLC entered a joint venture with Dianhong International Limited, Hong Kong, a subsidiary of Yunnan Dianhong Group Company Limited of China, to grow and process tea in Sri Lanka for Chinese Speciality Tea market.{{cite news | title = New BoI project signed to produce tea for Chinese market| newspaper = Ceylon Today | location = Colombo, Sri Lanka| date = 25 January 2013 | url = http://www.ceylontoday.lk/22-22854-news-detail-new-boi-project-signed-to-produce-tea-for-chinese-market.html| accessdate=9 October 2013}}{{cite news | title = Lankan Tea taps Chinese investment| newspaper = The Nation | location = Colombo, Sri Lanka| date = 27 January 2013 | url = http://www.nation.lk/edition/biz-news/item/15069-lankan-tea-taps-chinese-investment.html| accessdate=9 October 2013}} In April 2013, shares of Aitken Spence Plantation Managements Ltd was introduced to the Colombo Stock Exchange.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence Sri Lanka plantation unit to be listed| newspaper = Lanka Business Online | location = Colombo, Sri Lanka| date = 4 April 2013 | url = http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/news/Aitken_Spence_Sri_Lanka_plantation_unit_to_be_listed/1644914590| accessdate=9 October 2013}} ===Garment manufacturing=== Aitken Spence entered the garments manufacturing sector in 1979 with its factory at Mattakkuliya.{{cite news | title = Maldivian link saves the day for Aitken Spence| newspaper = Sunday Times| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 18 February 2001 | url = http://sundaytimes.lk/010218/busm.html| accessdate=9 October 2012}} Currently, Aitken Spence operates two factories in Sri Lanka—in [[Matugama]] (opened in 1993 in support of the 200 garment factories initiative of the then Government of Sri Lanka) and at Koggala Export Processing Zone (since 2008){{cite news | title = Aitken Spence Q3profit up by 16% to Rs 1.9b| newspaper = The Island| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 14 February 2008 | url = http://www.island.lk/2008/02/14/business7.html | accessdate=9 October 2012}}—that manufactures and exports high-quality men's/boys shirts, ladies/girls blouses, ladies skirts, pants and shorts for clients such as [[The Gap, Inc.]], [[Columbia Sportswear]], [[Kohl's]] and [[Sears]] in the US, and [[Marks & Spencer]] Work Wear, [[Sainsbury's]], [[Tesco]], [[Waitrose]], Boots and Marriot in Europe. Aitken Spence Garments have obtained a certification of Compliance+ from the Employers Federation of Ceylon and Platinum certified for compliance with Worldwide Responsible Accredited Production [[Worldwide Responsible Accredited Production|WRAP]]{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Annual Report 2017/2018|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=10 June 2018 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/annualreport/}} ===Printing=== In 1955, Clark Spence & Co. opened its own press to service its internal printing needs in Galle. Printing services were gradually opened for external parties and with the higher demand, the service offering was expanded with a full-fledged printing plant. Subsequently, in 1962, printing plant was moved from Galle to Colombo (Vauxhall St. Colombo 02 premises, where current Aitken Spence Group Headquarters is located) and ownership transferred to Aitken Spence & Co.{{cite web |url= http://aitkenspenceplc.wordpress.com/2009/11/16/our-printing-heritage-2/|title= Our Printing Heritage |accessdate=9 October 2012}}{{cite news | title = Amherst, El Alamein and Aitken Spence | newspaper = Sunday Times| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | url = http://www.sundaytimes.lk/030406/plus/6.html| accessdate=15 May 2014}} [[File:Aitken Spence Green Printing Facility.JPG|thumb|x225px|Aitken Spence Green Printing Facility]] In 1977, whole printing department was burnt from a fire and its operations were halted. In 1982, a new printing plant was built at Bloemendhal Road, Colombo 13 to resume printing services. In 2010, due to capacity constraints, the company made a decision to relocate this printing plant yet again.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence Printing makes technology enhancements | newspaper = Sunday Times| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 24 October 2010 | url = http://www.sundaytimes.lk/101024/BusinessTimes/bt31.html| accessdate=9 October 2012}} In recognizing the demand for environmentally friendly printing services, Aitken Spence invested US$7 million to construct Sri Lanka's first green printing facility at Mawaramandiya in Kelaniya. The new printing press commenced commercial operations in July 2012.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence unveils country’s first green printing facility| newspaper = Daily Mirror| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 23 July 2012 | url = http://www.dailymirror.lk/business/other/20506-aitken-spence-unveils-countrys-first-green-printing-facility.html}}{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence Printing Facility Opens| newspaper = Daily News| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 25 July 2012 | url = http://www.dailynews.lk/2012/07/25/bus100.pdf}} Aitken Spence Printing & Packaging is in line with global standards such as ISO 14001: 2015 system standard - environmental management system, ISO 9001:2015 system standard while prioritizing sustainability by conforming to OHSAS 18001:2007.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence Printing retains top spot in industry for 4th consecutive year| newspaper = Mirror Business| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 19 January 2018 | url = http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Aitken-Spence-Printing-retains-top-spot-in-industry-for-th-consecutive-year-144233.html}}{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence Printing and Packaging renews CarbonNeutral certificate | newspaper = Mirror Business| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 25 January 2016 | url = http://www.dailymirror.lk/104091/aitken-spence-printing-and-packaging-renews-carbonneutral-certificate| accessdate=9 October 2017}} The prestigious Glaxo Smith Kline (GSK) 2016 Environmental Sustainability Award was also won by the company been recognized for its 'Integrated Green Supply Chain Strategy'.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence Printing Bags GSK 2016 Global Accolade | newspaper = Sunday Leader| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date = 26 March 2017 | url = http://www.thesundayleader.lk/2017/03/26/aitken-spence-printing-bags-gsk-2016-global-accolade/| accessdate=3 October 2017}} Currently the plant functions 24 hours a day, offering services to a wide cross section of sectors such as coffee table books, periodicals, magazines, and Annual Reports for local and international corporate clients.{{cite web |url= http://aitkenspenceplc.wordpress.com/2010/05/13/ace-printing-to-soar-to-greater-heights/|title= Aitken Spence Printing to soar to greater heights |accessdate=9 October 2012}} Aitken Spence Printing was the first printer to introduce the concept of printed, illustrated and bound Annual Reports for companies in Sri Lanka in the 1980s. Aitken Spence Printing also produces several magazines for different publishing companies in Sri Lanka, as well as paperback books for publishers in the UK and USA. The production of printed packaging materials represents about 80 percent of business for the printing segment. In regards to packaging materials, it currently caters to major brands in garment industry, FMCG, cosmetics and pharmaceuticals in Sri Lanka. The company also caters to international clients such as [[Marks & Spencer]], British Home Stores, [[Tesco]] and DBA Europe. ===Next Generation Technology Products=== In October 2014, Aitken Spence invested in Eco Corp Asia, a company holding the exclusive rights in Sri Lanka to market nanotechnology based liquid glass coating product of Nanopool GmbH.{{cite news | title = Aitken Spence and Eco Corp Asia to take nanotechnology to next level| newspaper = Daily FT| location = Colombo, Sri Lanka | date =3 November 2014 | url = http://www.ft.lk/2014/11/03/aitken-spence-and-eco-corp-asia-to-take-nanotechnology-to-next-level/}} The operation formulates specialized surface protection systems and applications on different materials utilizing nanotechnology; while introducing diverse innovative solutions for industries.{{cite web |title= Aitken Spence Annual Report Ecocorp Asia 2017/2018|author= Aitken Spence |accessdate=5 July 2018 |url= http://aitkenspence.com/annualreport/}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.aitkenspence.com Official Website] * [http://www.marketwatch.com/investing/Stock/SPENN?CountryCode=LK The Wall Street Journal MarketWatch Overview] [[Category:Conglomerate companies of Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Publicly traded companies of Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Multinational companies]] [[Category:Hospitality companies of Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Logistics companies]] [[Category:Business process outsourcing companies]] [[Category:Energy companies]] [[Category:Hotel chains]]
