{{mergeto|Waste picker|date=May 2018}} [[File:Eugène Atget (French - Chiffonier (Ragpicker) - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|200px|right|A rag-picker in Paris, ca, 1899 - 1901.]] A '''Rag-picker''', or '''Chiffonnier''', is term for someone who makes a living by rummaging through [[refuse]] in the streets to collect material for salvage. Scraps of cloth and paper could be turned into [[Cardboard (paper product)|cardboard]], broken [[glass]] could be melted down and reused, and even dead cats and dogs could be [[Skinning|skinned]] to make clothes.
The rag-pickers in 19th and early 20th Century did not [[recycle]] the materials themselves; they would simply collect whatever they could find and turn it over to a "master rag-picker" (usually a former rag-picker) who would, in turn, sell it—generally by weight—to wealthy investors with the means to convert the materials into something more profitable.<ref name=Edwards>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oHIDAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA360&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Old and New Paris: Its history, its people, and its places|author=Edwards, Henry Sutherland|year=1893|pages=360–365|publisher=Cassell and Co.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Public Opinion|volume=36|chapter=The Workers in Waste Products|author=The Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|year=1904|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=atYaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA782&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
Although it was solely a job for the lowest of the [[working classes]], rag-picking was considered an honest [[Job (role)|occupation]], more on the level of [[street sweeper]] than of a [[beggar]]. In Paris, for instance, rag-pickers were regulated by law: their operations were restricted to certain times of night, and they were required to return any unusually valuable items to the owner or to the authorities.<ref name=Edwards/> When [[Eugène Poubelle]] introduced the [[garbage can]] in 1884, he was criticized in the French newspapers for meddling with the rag-pickers' livelihoods.<ref>{{cite book|author=Lynch, Hannah|year=1901|title=French life in town and country|publisher=Putnam|pages=278–279}}</ref> Modern [[sanitation]] and recycling programs ultimately caused the profession to decline, though it did not disappear entirely; [[rag and bone man|rag and bone men]] were still operating in the 1970s.
Rag-picking is still widespread in [[Third World]] countries today, such as in [[Mumbai]], [[India]], where it offers the poorest in society around the rubbish and recycling areas a chance to earn a hand-to-mouth supply of money. In 2015, the Environment Minister of India declared a national award to recognise the service rendered by rag-pickers. The award, with a cash prize of Rs. 1.5 lakh, is for three best rag pickers and three associations involved in innovation of best practices. <ref>http://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/energy-and-environment/rag-pickers-services-will-be-recognised-by-government-to-give-national-award/article7382780.ece</ref>
== Relationship in waste management and recycling == Ragpicking has a positive impact on urban spaces with a weak waste management infrastructure. In India, the economic activity of ragpicking is worth about ₹3200 crore. India was also found to have a near-90% recycle rate for PET bottles, which could probably be attributed to ragpicking, given a lack of solid-waste management and under-developed waste collection and recycling culture in that country. <ref>http://www.hindustantimes.com/mumbai-news/india-recycles-90-of-its-pet-waste-outperforms-japan-europe-and-us-study/story-yqphS1w2GdlwMYPgPtyb2L.html NCL and PET Packaging Association for Clean Environment (PACE) 2017年2月></ref>
==Legacy== *[[Charles Baudelaire]]'s ''[[Les Fleurs du Mal]]'' (1888) includes a poem where the rag-picker character has a prominent role, entitled "Le Vin de chiffonniers" ("The Rag-Picker's Wine"). *[[Francis Saltus Saltus]]' ''Shadows and Ideals'' (1890) includes a poem about rag-pickers entitled "The Old Rag-picker of Paris".<ref>{{cite book|title=Shadows and Ideals|author=Francis Saltus Saltus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YokPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA107&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=1890|publisher=C. W. Moulton}}</ref> *A section of tenement buildings near [[Chatham Square, Manhattan]] became known as Rag-picker's Court, as this was the profession of most of its residents. In 1879, [[William Allen Rogers]] drew the rag-strewn courtyard for ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' as part of a series of engravings focused on inner-city life.<ref>{{cite book|title=New York in the nineteenth century|author=Grafton, John|year=1977|page=62|isbn=978-0-486-23516-5|publisher=Dover Publications}}</ref> *In the 1862 novel ''[[Les Misérables]]'', the character Vargouleme is a rag-picker. He considers himself fortunate because, unlike many on the streets of Paris, he has a profession.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} * "[[Original Rags]]" is an 1899 musical medley for piano, an early example of the [[Ragtime]] genre, that makes reference to rag picking, as well as a pun * "[[Rag and Bone (song)|Rag and Bone]]" is a song by the American [[garage rock]] band [[The White Stripes]], told from the point of view of two rag and bone collectors. * ''[[The Ragpicker's Dream]]'' is a song and album by songwriter/guitarist [[Mark Knopfler]] released in 2002.

'''Schreinemaker's Analysis''' is the use of Schreinemaker's Rules to create a [[phase diagram]]. After applying Schreinemaker's Rules and creating a phase diagram, the resulting geometric figure will be [[thermodynamics|thermodynamically]] accurate, although the [[axe]]s will be undetermined. In order to determine the correct orientation of the [[geometric figure]] obtained through Schreinemaker's Rules, one must have additional information about the given [[chemical reaction|reactions]] or go through an analytical treatment of the thermodynamics of the relevant [[Phase (matter)|phases]]. ==Metastable extensions== Univariant lines are sometimes called [[chemical reaction|reaction]] lines. The extension of a univariant line through the invariant point is called the '''metastable extension'''. Univariant lines are usually drawn as a solid line while their metastable extensions are drawn as a dotted line. Univariant lines and their metastable extensions are often labeled by putting in square brackets the phase that is absent from the reaction associated with the given univariant line. In other words, since every univariant line represents a [[chemical equilibrium]], these equilibrium curves are named with the phase (or phases) that is ''not'' involved in the equilibrium. Take an example with four phases: A, B, C, D. If a univariant line is defined by the equilibrium reaction A+D←→C, this univariant line would be labeled [B], because the phase B is absent from the reaction A+D←→C. ==Morey-Schreinemaker Coincidence Theorem== The '''Morey-Schreinemaker Coincidence Theorem''' states that for every univariant line that passes through the invariant point, one side is stable and the other is [[metastable]]. The invariant point marks the boundary of the stable and metastable segments of a reaction line. ===Phase Rule=== {{main|phase rule}} An invariant point is defined as a representation of an invariant system (0 degrees of freedom by Gibbs' [[phase rule]]) by a point on a phase diagram. A univariant line thus represents a univariant system with 1 degree of freedom. Two univariant lines can then define a divariant area with 2 degrees of freedom. ===Metastable Extensions Rule=== From the '''Morey-Schreinemaker Coincidence Theorem''', Schreinemaker's Rules can be determined. These rules can be used in the creation of an accurate [[phase diagram]] where both [[Cartesian coordinate system|axes]] are [[intensive quantity|intensive]] thermodynamic variables. There are many correct collections of "Schreinemaker's Rules" and the choice to use a given set of rules depends on the nature of the phase diagrams being created. Due to the phrasing of the Morey-Schreinemaker Coincidence Theorem, only one rule is essential to the Schreinemaker's Rules. This is the so-called '''metastable extensions rule''':
''The metastable extension of the [phase-absent] reaction must fall in the sector in which that phase is stable in all possible assemblages.''Spear, Frank S. ''Metamorphic Phase Equilibria and Pressure-Temperature-Time Paths''. Washington, D.C: Mineralogical Society of America, 1995.
[[File:Generic_phase_diagram.jpg|thumb|300px|right|A generic phase diagram with unspecified axes; the invariant point is marked in red, metastable extensions labeled in blue, relevant reactions noted on stable ends of univariant lines.]] This rule is geometrically sound in the construction of [[phase diagrams]] since for every metastable reaction, there must be a phase that is relatively stable. This phase must be the one which does not participate in the reaction and is therefore not consumed as a reactant or formed as a product, thus being "stable." Some collections of '''Schreinemaker's Rules''' will contain the following, additional, basic statements: * No assemblage has a stability area greater than 180°. * All reactants and products are stable in the field where the reaction plots. * The absent phase is unstable where the reaction plots. * Complex reactions (high number of participating phases) ''usually'' lie within bounding, simple reactions defining the phase stability region. * The simplest divariant region ''usually'' contains the most metastable extensions. * If each stable and metastable reaction curve is labeled with the absent phase, then the order of the named curves as you proceed around the invariant point should cycle through all phases twice in order of their relative reaction components. ====Assemblages==== An '''assemblage''' is defined as the phases on one side of an equilibrium reaction. An assemblage can be either a single phase or a collection of phases. In the example above with the equilibrium reaction A+D←→C, (A+D) is an assemblage as well as (C) on its own. ==External links== * [http://serc.carleton.edu/research_education/equilibria/schreinemakers.html Schreinemakers Method] ==References== [[Category:Phase transitions]] [[Category:Diagrams]]

{{Redirect|Slosh|the storm surge model|Sea, Lake, and Overland Surge from Hurricanes|the typographical symbol|backslash}} [[File:Slosh in Pool 20150719.jpg|thumb|Water sloshing in the swimming pool of a cruise ship undergoing pitching motion]] In [[fluid dynamics]], '''slosh''' refers to the movement of [[liquid]] inside another object (which is, typically, also undergoing motion).
Strictly speaking, the liquid must have a [[free surface]] to constitute a '''slosh dynamics''' problem, where the dynamics of the liquid can interact with the container to alter the system dynamics significantly.<ref>Moiseyev, N.N. & V.V. Rumyantsev. "Dynamic Stability of Bodies Containing Fluid." Springer-Verlag, 1968.</ref> Important examples include [[propellant]] slosh in [[spacecraft]] tanks and [[rocket]]s (especially upper stages), and the [[free surface effect]] (cargo slosh) in ships and trucks transporting liquids (for example oil and gasoline). However, it has become common to refer to liquid motion in a completely filled tank, i.e. without a free surface, as "fuel slosh".{{Citation needed lead|date=August 2011}}
Such motion is characterized by "[[inertial wave]]s" and can be an important effect in spinning spacecraft dynamics. Extensive mathematical and empirical relationships have been derived to describe liquid slosh.<ref>{{cite book| last=Ibrahim| first=Raouf A.| title=Liquid Sloshing Dynamics: Theory and Applications| year=2005| publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0521838856|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ctvhvH74ZzEC&dq=liquid+slosh+ibrahim&printsec=frontcover&source=bn&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result#v=onepage&q=liquid%20slosh%20ibrahim&f=false}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Sloshing|last = Faltinsen|first = Odd M.|publisher = Cambridge University press|year = 2009|isbn = 978-0521881111|location = |pages = |last2 = Timokha|first2 = Alexander N.}}</ref> These types of analyses are typically undertaken using [[computational fluid dynamics]] and [[finite element methods]] to solve the [[fluid-structure interaction]] problem, especially if the solid container is flexible. Relevant fluid dynamics non-dimensional parameters include the [[Bond number]], the [[Weber number]], and the [[Reynolds number]].
Slosh is an important effect for spacecraft,<ref>Reyhanoglu, M. "Maneuvering control problems for a spacecraft with unactuated fuel slosh dynamics". Control Applications, 2003. Proc 2003 IEEE Conference. Volume 1, 23–25 June 2003, pp695-699.</ref> ships,<ref name=":0" /> and some [[aircraft]]. Slosh was a factor in the [[Falcon 1]] second test flight anomaly, and has been implicated in various other spacecraft anomalies, including a near-disaster<ref>Veldman, A.E.P. et al. "The Numerical Simulation of Liquid Sloshing On-Board Spacecraft." J. Comput. Phys. 224 (2007) 82-99.</ref> with the Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous ([[NEAR Shoemaker]]) satellite.
== Spacecraft effects == Liquid slosh in [[microgravity]]<ref>Monti, R. "Physics of Fluids in Microgravity." CRC, 2002.</ref><ref>Antar, B.N. & V.S. Nuotio-Antar. "Fundamentals of Low Gravity Fluid Dynamics and Heat Transfer." CRC, 1994.</ref> is relevant to spacecraft, most commonly Earth-orbiting [[satellites]], and must take account of liquid [[surface tension]] which can alter the shape (and thus the [[eigenvalues]]) of the liquid slug. Typically, a large part of the mass fraction of a satellite is liquid propellant at/near Beginning of Life (BOL), and slosh can adversely affect satellite performance in a number of ways. For example, propellant slosh can introduce uncertainty in spacecraft attitude (pointing) which is often called [[jitter]]. Similar phenomena can cause [[pogo oscillation]] and can result in structural failure of space vehicle.
Another example is problematic interaction with the spacecraft Attitude Control System (ACS), especially for spinning satellites<ref>Hubert, C. "Behavior of Spinning Space Vehicles with Onboard Liquids." NASA GSFC Symposium, 2003.</ref> which can suffer [[resonance]] between slosh and [[nutation]], or adverse changes to the rotational [[inertia]]. Because of these types of [[risk]], in the 1960s the [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA) extensively studied<ref>Abramson, H.N. "The Dynamic Behavior of Liquids in Moving Containers." NASA SP-106, 1966.</ref> liquid slosh in spacecraft tanks, and in the 1990s NASA undertook the ''Middeck 0-Gravity Dynamics Experiment''<ref>Crawley, E.F. & M.C. Van Schoor & E.B. Bokhour. "The Middeck 0-Gravity Dynamics Experiment: Summary Report", NASA-CR-4500, Mar 1993.</ref> on the [[space shuttle]]. The [[European Space Agency]] has advanced these investigations<ref>Vreeburg, J.P.B. "Measured States of SLOSHSAT FLEVO", IAC-05-C1.2.09, Oct 2005.</ref><ref>Prins, J.J.M. "SLOSHSAT FLEVO Project, Flight and Lessons Learned", IAC-05-B5.3./B5.5.05, Oct 2005.</ref><ref>Luppes, R. & J.A. Helder & A.E.P. Veldman. "Liquid Sloshing in Microgravity", IAC-05-A2.2.07, Oct 2005.</ref><ref>Vreeburg, J.P.B. "SLOSHSAT Spacecraft Calibration at Stationary Spin Rates." J. Spacecraft & Rockets, v45, n1, p65, Jan/Feb 2008.</ref> with the launch of [[Sloshsat-FLEVO|SLOSHSAT]]. Most spinning spacecraft since 1980 have been tested at the Applied Dynamics Laboratories drop tower using sub-scale models.<ref>{{cite web|title=Partial List of Spacecraft Tested by ADL|url=http://www.fuelslosh.com/SPACECRAFT.html|work=Applied Dynamics Laboratories| accessdate=30 April 2013}}</ref> Extensive contributions have also been made<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swri.org/3pubs/brochure/d04/fdynspac/fdynspac.htm |title=18-Fluid Dynamics in Space Vehicles Brochure |publisher=Swri.org |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> by the [[Southwest Research Institute]], but research is widespread<ref>{{cite web| url=http://sloshcentral.bbbeard.org/ |title=Slosh Central |publisher=Sloshcentral.bbbeard.org |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> in academia and industry.
Research is continuing into slosh effects on in-[[outer space|space]] [[propellant depot]]s. In October 2009, the [[U.S. Air Force|Air Force]] and [[United Launch Alliance]] (ULA) performed an experimental [[low-Earth orbit|on-orbit]] demonstration on a modified [[Centaur (rocket stage)#Test bed for cryogenic fluid management experiments|Centaur upper stage]] on the [[DMSP-18]] satellite [[Atlas V#Atlas V launches|launch]] in order to improve "understanding of [[Propellant depot#Propellant settling|propellant settling]] and slosh", "The light weight of DMSP-18 allowed {{convert|12000|lbs}} of remaining LO<sub>2</sub> and LH<sub>2</sub> propellant, 28% of Centaur’s capacity", for the on-orbit tests. The post-spacecraft mission extension ran 2.4 hours before the planned [[Impulsive maneuver|deorbit burn]] was executed.<ref name=ula200910> [http://www.ulalaunch.com/site/docs/publications/SuccessfulFlightDemonstrationConductedbytheAirForceandUnitedLaunchAllianceWillEnhanceSpaceTransportation_.pdf ulalaunch.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717153030/http://www.ulalaunch.com/site/docs/publications/SuccessfulFlightDemonstrationConductedbytheAirForceandUnitedLaunchAllianceWillEnhanceSpaceTransportation_.pdf |date=2011-07-17 }}; Successful Flight Demonstration Conducted by the Air Force and United Launch Alliance Will Enhance Space Transportation: DMSP-18, ''[[United Launch Alliance]]'', October 2009, accessed 2011-01-10.</ref>
NASA's [[Launch Services Program]] is working on two on-going [[Launch Services Program#Slosh Fluid Dynamics Experiments|slosh fluid dynamics experiments]] with partners: [[CRYOTE]] and [[SPHERES]]-Slosh.<ref>[http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/experiments/980.html nasa.gov]</ref> ULA has additional small-scale demonstrations of cryogenic fluid management are planned with project CRYOTE in 2012-2014<ref name=fiso20101110/> leading to a ULA large-scale cryo-sat propellant depot test under the NASA [[flagship technology demonstrations]] program in 2015.<ref name=fiso20101110> [http://spirit.as.utexas.edu/~fiso/telecon/Kutter_11-10-10/Kutter_11-10-10.pdf spirit.as.utexas.edu] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110206042325/http://spirit.as.utexas.edu/~fiso/telecon/Kutter_11-10-10/Kutter_11-10-10.pdf |date=2011-02-06 }}; ''Propellant Depots Made Simple'', Bernard Kutter, [[United Launch Alliance]], FISO Colloquium, 2010-11-10, accessed 2011-01-10.</ref> SPHERES-Slosh with [[Florida Institute of Technology]] and [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] will examine how liquids move around inside containers in microgravity with the SPHERES Testbed on the [[International Space Station]].
== Sloshing in road tank vehicles == Liquid sloshing strongly influences the directional dynamics and safety performance of highway [[Tank truck|tank vehicles]] in a highly adverse manner.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kolaei|first=Amir|last2=Rakheja|first2=Subhash|last3=Richard|first3=Marc J.|date=2016-01-25|title=An efficient methodology for simulating roll dynamics of a tank vehicle coupled with transient fluid slosh|url=http://jvc.sagepub.com/content/early/2016/01/23/1077546315627565|journal=Journal of Vibration and Control|language=en|pages=1077546315627565|doi=10.1177/1077546315627565|issn=1077-5463}}</ref> Hydrodynamic [[force]]s and [[moment (physics)|moment]]s arising from liquid [[cargo]] oscillations in the tank under [[steering]] and/or [[braking]] maneuvers reduce the stability limit and controllability of partially-filled [[Tank truck|tank vehicles]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kolaei|first=Amir|last2=Rakheja|first2=Subhash|last3=Richard|first3=Marc J.|date=2014-01-06|title=Range of applicability of the linear fluid slosh theory for predicting transient lateral slosh and roll stability of tank vehicles|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022460X13007360|journal=Journal of Sound and Vibration|volume=333|issue=1|pages=263–282|doi=10.1016/j.jsv.2013.09.002|bibcode=2014JSV...333..263K}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kolaei|first=Amir|last2=Rakheja|first2=Subhash|last3=Richard|first3=Marc J.|date=2014-07-01|title=Effects of tank cross-section on dynamic fluid slosh loads and roll stability of a partly-filled tank truck|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0997754614000107|journal=European Journal of Mechanics B|volume=46|pages=46–58|doi=10.1016/j.euromechflu.2014.01.008|bibcode=2014EJMF...46...46K}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kolaei|first=Amir|last2=Rakheja|first2=Subhash|last3=Richard|first3=Marc J.|date=2015-09-01|title=Three-dimensional dynamic liquid slosh in partially-filled horizontal tanks subject to simultaneous longitudinal and lateral excitations|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0997754615000746|journal=European Journal of Mechanics B|volume=53|pages=251–263|doi=10.1016/j.euromechflu.2015.06.001|bibcode=2015EJMF...53..251K}}</ref> Anti-slosh devices such as baffles are widely used in order to limit the adverse liquid slosh effect on directional performance and stability of the [[Tank truck|tank vehicles]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kolaei|first=Amir|last2=Rakheja|first2=Subhash|last3=Richard|first3=Marc J.|date=2015-01-31|title=A coupled multimodal and boundary-element method for analysis of anti-slosh effectiveness of partial baffles in a partly-filled container|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0045793014004186|journal=Computers & Fluids|volume=107|pages=43–58|doi=10.1016/j.compfluid.2014.10.013}}</ref> Since most of the time, tankers are carrying dangerous liquid contents such as ammonia, gasoline and fuel oils; therefore stability of partially-filled liquid cargo vehicles is very important. Optimizations and sloshing reduction techniques in fuel tanks such as elliptical tank, rectangular, modified oval and generic tank shape have been performed in different filling levels using numerical, analytical and analogical analyses. Most of these studies concentrate on effects of baffles on sloshing while the influence of cross-section is completely ignored.<ref name="ssdfss">{{cite journal | last1 = Talebitooti | first1 = R.| last2 = shojaeefard | first2 = M.H.| last3 = Yarmohammadisatri | first3 = Sadegh | year = 2015 | title = Shape design optimization of cylindrical tank using b-spline curves | url = | journal = computer & fluids | volume = 109 | pages = 100–112 | doi= 10.1016/j.compfluid.2014.12.004 }}</ref>
The Bloodhound SSC 1,000 mph project car utilizes a liquid-fuelled rocket that requires a specially-baffled oxidizer tank to prevent directional instability, rocket thrust variations and even oxidizer tank damage.<ref>http://www.bloodhoundssc.com/blog/29-importance-slosh-and-slam</ref>
== Practical effects == Sloshing or shifting [[cargo]], water [[Sailing ballast|ballast]], or other liquid (e.g. from leaks or fire fighting) can cause disastrous [[capsize|capsizing]] in ships due to [[free surface effect]]; this can also affect trucks and aircraft.
The effect of slosh is used to limit the bounce of a [[roller hockey]] ball. Water slosh can significantly reduce the rebound height of a ball<ref>Sport ball for roller hockey; U.S. Patent 5516098; May 14, 1996; Jeffrey Aiello.</ref> but some amounts of liquid seem to lead to a [[resonance]] effect. Many of the balls for roller hockey commonly available contain water to reduce the bounce height.
== See also == * [[Seiche]], a phenomenon affecting lakes and other constrained bodies of water * [[Splash (fluid mechanics)]], other free surface phenomena * [[Succussion splash]], audible medical sign
== References == {{reflist|2}}
=== Other references=== * {{en icon}} Meserole, J.S., A. Fortini (1987), “Slosh Dynamics in a Toroidal Tank,” Journal Spacecraft, Volume 24, Number 6, November–December 1987 * {{en icon}} NASA (1969), ''[http://www.dept.aoe.vt.edu/~cdhall/courses/aoe4065/NASADesignSPs/sp8031.pdf Slosh suppression]'', May 1969, PDF, 36p * {{en icon}} NASA (1966), ''[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19670006555.pdf Dynamic behavior of liquids in moving containers with applications to propellants in space vehicle fuel tanks]'', Jan 1, 1966, PDF, 464 p

{{Infobox company | name = Solar Euromed | logo = [[File:SolarEuromed company logo.jpg|alt=Solar Euromed Logo|Solar Euromed Logo]] | type =[[Privately held company|Privately held]] | foundation = 2007 | defunct = 2016 | location_city = [[Dijon]] | location_country = France | industry = Concentrated Solar Power Technology | homepage = [http://www.solareuromed.com/ solareuromed.com] }}
'''Solar Euromed''' is a high technology group based in [[France]] specialized in [[concentrated solar power]] technology,<ref>[http://www.emerging-energy.com/uploadDocs/GlobalConcentratedSolarPowerMarketsandStrategies2010.pdf|work=Global Concentrated Solar Power Markets and Strategies 2010-2025. April 2010]</ref> in activity from 2007 to 2016.
The company provides proprietary [[concentrated solar power|solar thermal power systems]] which produce [[heat]] for [[power generation]] and [[List of industrial processes|industrial applications]] with the built-in ability to [[Energy storage|store energy]] and [[Electricity generation|supply electricity]] on demand, even after [[sunset]]. Solar Euromed's [[concentrated solar power|solar thermal technology]] is based on the concept of [[Solar thermal energy|direct steam generation]] and [[Optics|linear Fresnel optics]] and was developed together with the [[French National Centre for Scientific Research]] and the [[Commissariat à l'énergie atomique|French Atomic Energy and Alternative Energies Commission]].<ref>[http://www.solareuromed.com/sites/default/files/Les%20Echos_SEM%20pr%C3%AAt%20%C3%A0%20construire%20une%20centrale%20solaire%20en%20Corse_11_0.pdf Les Echos - Solar Euromed prêt à construire une centrale solaire en Corse]</ref>
==History== Since its inception, Solar Euromed has been an active promoter of [[concentrated solar power|CSP]] technology in [[Europe]] and has built a recognized expertise in this emerging field:<ref>[http://www.dalkia.com/en/news-media/press-releases/2008-09-15,thermo-dynamic-solar-project.htm France's first thermo-dynamic solar project] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724035942/http://www.dalkia.com/en/news-media/press-releases/2008-09-15,thermo-dynamic-solar-project.htm |date=2011-07-24 }}</ref>
* In 2007, Solar Euromed developed the Solenha project ultimately classified as [http://ec.europa.eu/environment/seveso/index.htm Seveso] enabling a greater knowledge<ref>[http://www.solareuromed.com/sites/default/files/SEM_TR11_HIPT_001_print_0.pdf Solar Euromed - Hazard issues in Parabolic Trough Technology]</ref> in the [[environmental impact assessment]] of [[Solar thermal energy|parabolic trough]] technology.<ref>[http://www.liberation.fr/terre/0101562941-solenha-retard-a-l-allumage Liberation - Solenha]</ref> * In 2009, the group launched its technology development plan funded by the French innovation fund [[:fr:Oséo|Oseo]] and the [[European Union]] which initially resulted in a Fresnel-based pilot plant located at the [[Themis (solar power plant)|Themis solar energy R&D platform]] in the [[Pyreneans]].<ref>[http://tecsol.blogs.com/mon_weblog/2011/07/solar-euromed-poursuit-son-d%C3%A9veloppement-dans-le-solaire-%C3%A0-concentration.html Tecsol - Solar Euromed's development]</ref> * In 2010, the company signed a 2 GW agreement with the [[Sudan|Republic of Sudan]] for the development, construction and operation of CSP plants to be implemented over the next decade. Few weeks later, Solar Euromed signed a [[power purchase agreement]] for the realization of the first 250 MW.<ref>[http://www.evwind.es/noticias.php?id_not=4915 REVE - Solar Euromed signed an agreement for a 2 GW Solar in Sudan]</ref> * In 2011, it secured in [[Corsica]] a [[construction permit]] for the implementation of the largest solar thermal power plant in France set to demonstrate Solar Euromed’s proprietary Fresnel-based technology at utility scale.<ref>[http://www.helioscsp.com/noticia.php?id_not=523 Helionoticias - Authorities award construction permit for the first CSP plant in France] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321184115/http://www.helioscsp.com/noticia.php?id_not=523 |date=2012-03-21 }}</ref> * In September 2015, the company was placed under [[administration (law)|administration]].<ref>{{cite web|language=fr|url=http://www.greenunivers.com/2016/01/y-a-t-il-un-repreneur-pour-solar-euromed-137700/|title=Y a-t-il un repreneur pour Solar Euromed ?|date=January 7, 2016 |author=Anne-Claire Poirier|website=greenunivers.com|access-date=January 10, 2016}}</ref> It was finally shut down in September 2016.<ref>{{cite web|language=fr|url=http://www.bienpublic.com/edition-dijon-ville/2016/09/13/solar-euromed-a-ete-placee-en-liquidation-judiciaire|title=Solar Euromed a été placée en liquidation judiciaire|date=2016-09-13|access-date=2016-10-20|website=bienpublic.com}}</ref>
==Concentrated solar power== [[Concentrated solar power|CSP]] technologies concentrate [[energy]] from the [[sun]]’s rays to heat a [[fluid]] to high temperatures. This heat is transformed into [[mechanical energy]] and then into [[electricity]]. Using the [[sun]] as a free source of [[energy]], structures made out of [[metal]] and [[glass]] and completely [[greenhouse gas]] (GHG) emission-free, [[Concentrated Solar Power]] is a [[sustainable]] and [[environmentally friendly]] solution to produce a [[Sustainable energy|clean]] and [[renewable]] energy.<ref>[http://www.rtcc.org/2010/html/solar-euromed.html Responding to climate change 2010 - CSP – The fully sustainable solution] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527113349/http://www.rtcc.org/2010/html/solar-euromed.html |date=2010-05-27 }}</ref>
CSP is a proven technology and the first plants began operating in [[California]] in the 80’s, spurred by federal and state tax incentives and mandatory long-term [[power purchase agreement|power purchase contracts]]. A drop in [[fossil fuel]] prices then led the federal and state governments to dismantle the [[policy]] framework that had supported the advancement of CSP. In 2006, the market re-emerged in [[Spain]] and the [[United States]], supported by changes in governmental policies favorable to [[renewable energies]] – and [[solar energy|solar]] in particular. CSP uses [[renewable]] [[Solar energy|solar resource]] to [[Electricity generation|generate electricity]] while producing no [[GHG emissions]] (SO<small>X</small>, CO<small>2</small>) with large scale power capacities. CSP plants can be combined with [[thermal storage]] capacity so as to avoid [[intermittency]] due to [[clouds]], or to provide the [[Electrical grid|grid]] with [[electricity]] in the [[evening]], during [[peak hours]], and throughout the [[night]]. CSP plants can also provide power generation during off-solar hours thanks to [[Orbital hybridisation|hybridization]] either with [[gas]] or [[biomass]]. While the bulk of CSP electricity will come from large, on-grid power plants, these technologies also show significant potential for supplying other specific needs such as [[water desalination]], [[off-grid]] [[power generation|power]], [[combined heat and power generation]], [[process heat]], oil & gas [[pump]]ing, and [[Hydrogen economy|solar fuels generation]].<ref>[http://www.iea.org/papers/2010/csp_roadmap.pdf International Energy Agency CSP Roadmap ]</ref>
==Technology== Solar Euromed's technology use long and narrow segments of [[mirror]] that pivot to [[Reflection (physics)|reflect]] the [[sunlight]] onto a fixed [[Solar thermal collector|absorber tube]] located at the common focal line of the reflectors. A secondary reflector enables to have a higher [[heat flux]] and [[homogeneous]] [[heating]] of the absorber tube which can generate [[temperatures]] up to 450 °C. Solar Euromed's solutions include a large scale assembly of Fresnel reflector modules working with direct steam generation at high temperature, a thermal storage capacity, a scheme of assembly enabling [[farming]] under the reflectors due to the high positioning of the structures, and the use of recyclable materials limiting waste during the dismantling and the [[environmental impact]].<ref>[http://www.neo-planete.com/2011/06/22/solar-euromed-developpe-les-centrales-solaires-a-concentration/ Solar Euromed CEO's interview on technology]</ref><ref>[http://www.electroiq.com/photovoltaics/2011/08/1474394352/french-solar-euromed-launches-fund-raising-for-solar-project-in-corsica.html Renewables news network - French Solar Euromed launches fund-raising for solar project in Corsica] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120905234112/http://www.electroiq.com/photovoltaics/2011/08/1474394352/french-solar-euromed-launches-fund-raising-for-solar-project-in-corsica.html |date=2012-09-05 }}</ref>
'''Advantages of the technology'''
Fresnel technology has CSP’s best land-to-electricity [[ratio]] due to a compact [[design]] and the [[usability]] of space below support structures. This technology is also considered to be cheaper to implement and allows a strong [[construction]] modularity. Fresnel system requires flat or less-shaped [[mirror]]s and facilitates Direct Steam Generation, eliminating the need for costly [[Coolant|heat transfer fluids]] and [[heat exchangers]]. Moreover, [[Maintenance, repair, and operations|operations and maintenance]] are easy, hence, the associated [[cost]]s are moderate.<ref>[http://www.greenunivers.com/2011/07/solar-euromed-monte-en-pression-sur-le-solaire-thermodynamique-premium-60049/ Greenunivers.com - CSP technology by Solar Euromed]</ref>
'''Pilot Plant'''
In [[partnership]] with two leading French R&D centers ([[CNRS]] and [[Commissariat à l'énergie atomique|CEA]]),<ref>[http://www.solareuromed.com/en/partners/science-and-technology Solar Euromed - R&D partnerships]</ref> Solar Euromed has implemented this landmark technology development into a fully instrumented MW-size pilot plant called Augustin Fresnel 1 located in the French [[Pyreneans]].<ref>[http://www.solareuromed.com/en/vision/innovate/augustin-fresnel-1 Augustin Fresnel 1 official description]</ref>
==Alba Nova 1==
Located at [[Ghisonaccia]] in [[Corsica]], Alba Nova 1 is Solar Euromed's [[Concentrated solar power|CSP]] demonstration plant for which a [[construction permit]] was already secured for a net [[Electric power|power output]] of 12 MW producing [[electricity]] equivalent of the consumption of 10 000 households, thus serving as a bridge between the pilot phase and the anticipated deployment in the [[MENA]] region. It provides an optimized integration of [[agricultural]] activities under the supporting structures and a state-of-the art [[eco-friendly]] overall [[design]]. It is the first CSP project to be authorized in France since more than 30 years<ref>[https://archive.is/20120913083021/http://www.tenerrdis.fr/rep-edito/p-456.html Tenerrdis - Permit granted for Solar Euromed]</ref> and serves as a reference for the [[Energy transformation|energy conversion]] and [[economic]] performance of Solar Euromed’s Fresnel proprietary technology. Due to its [[island|insularity]], [[Corsica]] has specific energetic constraints to operate with limited connections to an external network, protection of [[Natural environment|environment]], [[fire]], and has to manage the downward looking lifecycle of two fossil-powered thermal [[power plants]].<ref>[http://www.corsematin.com/article/haute-corse/une-centrale-solaire-en-projet Corse Matin newspaper - Une centrale solaire en projet]</ref>

'''Solar bonds''' are [[Municipal bond|municipal]] [[revenue bond]]s issued to provide low-interest financing for lower-cost accelerated development of local [[renewable energy]] technologies such as [[solar power]].
==History== The first solar bond authority was drafted by [[Paul Douglas Fenn]], creator of [[Community Choice Aggregation]], and approved by [[San Francisco, California]] voters in 2001.<ref>http://www.local.org/hbondlnk.html</ref> Under "solar neighborhoods" approach, municipal governments would enter into multi-decade community-wide [[power purchase agreement]]s with competitive suppliers and issue solar bonds, or "H Bonds", to finance the new supplier's rollout of local renewable energy and [[efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] measures, offering municipal bond financing to residents and businesses, the debt for which would be repaid on monthly electric bills - an approach that has come to be called "on-bill financing." <ref>{{cite web|title=Financing Green Projects|url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2008/03/financing-green-projects-51766|accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref>
The City of San Francisco enshrined solar bonds in its Community Choice Aggregation program in 2004 when it adopted an ordinance combining the City's authority to procure power for its residents and businesses with its authority to issue revenue bonds under the solar bond authority. Fenn drafted the ordinance (86-04, 2004) for sponsoring supervisor [[Tom Ammiano]], who had also sponsored placing the solar bond authority on the 2001 ballot, and Fenns' company, Local Power Inc., went on to draft a 2007 implementation plan and 2013 business model to implement the $1 billion project.<ref>{{cite web|title=San Francisco's Green Power Plan Still Stalled by Corporate Interests a Decade Later|url=http://truth-out.org/news/item/18347-considered-a-national-example-san-franciscos-green-power-plan-has-struggled-for-a-decade-to-overcome-opposition-from-monopoly-corporate-interests|accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref> Local Power also contributed substantially to Sonoma county's Sonoma Clean Power program which has a similar structure.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Bottom Line|url=http://www.metroactive.com/bohemian/11.23.11/news-1147.html|accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=$1 Million RESCO Grant Approved for Energy Independence Projects|url=http://scwa2.computergrafixco.com/eNews/index.asp?issue=5/1/2009&campaign=Enews&article=2113|accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref>
Apart from creating a new generation of Community Choice Aggregations, San Francisco's solar bond authority spawned the subsequent appearance of both public and private financing of customer-owned solar and [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] measures, including [[PACE financing]] and the solar [[power purchase agreement]] or PPA, transforming the photovoltaics industry in the United States.

page.title: Thermal boundary layer thickness and shape

revision.text:
[[File:Thermal Boundary Layer Thickness formed by heated fluid flow along a plate.jpg|thumb|400px|Schematic drawing depicting heated fluid flow over a flat plate.]]
This page describes some parameters used to characterize the properties of the '''thermal boundary layer''' formed by a heated (or cooled) fluid moving along a heated (or cooled) wall. In many ways, the thermal boundary layer description parallels the [[boundary layer|velocity (momentum) boundary layer]] description first conceptualized by [[Ludwig Prandtl]].<ref>L. Prandtl, “Über Flüssigkeitsbewegung bei sehr kleiner Reibung,” Verhandlungen des Dritten Internationalen Mathematiker-Kongresses in Heidelberg 1904, A. Krazer, ed., Teubner, Leipzig, (1905) 484–491.</ref> Consider a fluid of uniform temperature <math>T_o</math> and velocity <math>u_o</math> impinging onto a stationary plate uniformly heated to a temperature <math>T_s</math>. Assume the flow and the plate are semi-infinite in the positive/negative direction perpendicular to the <math>x-y</math> plane. As the fluid flows along the wall, the fluid at the wall surface satisfies a [[no-slip boundary condition]] and has zero velocity, but as you move away from the wall, the velocity of the flow asymptotically approaches the free stream velocity <math>u_0</math>. The temperature at the solid wall is <math>T_s</math> and gradually changes to <math>T_o</math> as one moves toward the free stream of the fluid. It is impossible to define a sharp point at which the thermal boundary layer fluid or the velocity boundary layer fluid becomes the free stream, yet these layers have a well-defined characteristic thickness given by <math>\delta_T</math> and <math>\delta_v</math>. The parameters below provide a useful definition of this characteristic, measurable thickness for the thermal boundary layer. Also included in this boundary layer description are some parameters useful in describing the shape of the thermal boundary layer.
== 99% Thermal Boundary Layer thickness == The '''thermal boundary layer thickness''', '''<math>\delta_T</math>''', is the distance across a boundary layer from the wall to a point where the flow temperature has essentially reached the 'free stream' temperature, <math>T_0</math>. This distance is defined normal to the wall in the <math>y</math>-direction. The thermal boundary layer thickness is customarily defined as the point in the boundary layer, <math>y_{99}</math>, where the temperature <math>T(x,y)</math> reaches 99% of the free stream value <math>T_0</math>: :<math>\delta_T = y_{99}</math> such that <math>T(x,y_{99})</math> = 0.99 <math>T_0</math> at a position <math>x</math> along the wall. In a real fluid, this quantity can be estimated by measuring the temperature profile at a position <math>x </math> along the wall. The temperature profile is the temperature as a function of <math>y</math> at a fixed <math>x</math> position.
For [[laminar flow]] over a flat plate a zero incidence, the thermal boundary layer thickness is given by:<ref>Schlichting, p. 307.</ref> :<math> \delta_T = \delta_v \mathrm{Pr}^{-1/3} </math> :<math> \delta_T = 5.0 \sqrt{ {\nu x}\over u_0} \mathrm{Pr}^{-1/3}</math>
where :<math>\mathrm{Pr}</math> is the [[Prandtl Number]] :<math>\delta_v</math> is the thickness of the [[boundary layer thickness|velocity boundary layer thickness]] <ref>Schlichting, p.140.</ref> :<math>u_0</math> is the freestream velocity :<math>x</math> is the distance downstream from the start of the boundary layer :<math>\nu</math> is the [[kinematic viscosity]]
For [[turbulent flow]] over a flat plate, the thickness of the thermal boundary layer that is formed is not determined by thermal diffusion, but instead, it is random fluctuations in the outer region of the boundary layer of the fluid that is the driving force determining thermal boundary layer thickness. Thus the thermal boundary layer thickness for turbulent flow does not depend on the [[Prandtl number]] but instead on the [[Reynolds number]]. Hence, the turbulent thermal boundary layer thickness is given approximately by the turbulent velocity [[boundary layer thickness]] expression<ref>Schlichting, p. 638.</ref> given by: :<math> \delta_T \approx \delta \approx 0.37x/ {\mathrm{Re}_x}^{1/5} </math>
where :<math>{\mathrm{Re}_x}= u_0 x/\nu</math> is the [[Reynolds number]]
This turbulent boundary layer thickness formula assumes 1) the flow is turbulent right from the start of the boundary layer and 2) the turbulent boundary layer behaves in a geometrically similar manner (i.e. the velocity profiles are geometrically similar along the flow in the x-direction, differing only by stretching factors in <math>y</math> and <math>u(x,y)</math><ref>Schlichting, p.152.</ref>). Neither one of these assumptions is true for the general turbulent boundary layer case so care must be exercised in applying this formula.
== Thermal Displacement Thickness ==
The '''thermal displacement thickness''', '''<math>\beta^*</math>''' may be thought of in terms of the difference between a real fluid and a hypothetical fluid with thermal diffusion turned off but with velocity <math>u_0</math> and temperature <math>T_0</math>. With no thermal diffusion, the temperature drop is abrupt. The thermal displacement thickness is the distance by which the hypothetical fluid surface would have to be moved in the <math>y</math>-direction to give the same integrated temperature as occurs between the wall and the reference plane at <math>\delta_T</math> in the real fluid. It is a direct analog to the velocity displacement thickness which is often described in terms of an equivalent shift of a hypothetical inviscid fluid (see Schlichting<ref>Schlichting, p. 140.</ref> for velocity displacement thickness).
The definition of the thermal displacement thickness for incompressible flow is based on the integral of the reduced temperature:
:<math> {\beta^*}= \int_0^\infty {\theta(x,y) \,\mathrm{d}y}</math>
where the dimensionless temperature is <math>\theta(x,y) = (T(x,y)-T_0)/(T_s-T_0)</math>. In a [[wind tunnel]], the velocity and temperature profiles are obtained by measuring the velocity and temperature at many discrete <math>y</math>-values at a fixed <math>x</math>-position. The thermal displacement thickness can then be estimated by [[numerical integration|numerically integrating]] the scaled temperature profile.
== Moment Method == A relatively new method<ref>Weyburne, 2006.</ref><ref>Weyburne, 2018.</ref> for describing the thickness and shape of the thermal boundary layer utilizes the [[Moment (mathematics)|moment method]] commonly used to describe a random variable's [[probability distribution]]. The moment method was developed from the observation that the plot of the second derivative of the thermal profile for laminar flow over a plate looks very much like a [[Gaussian distribution]] curve.<ref>Weyburne, 2006, p. 1680.</ref> It is straightforward to cast the properly scaled thermal profile into a suitable integral kernel.
The thermal profile central moments are defined as: :<math> {\kappa_n} = {1\over\beta^*}\int_0^\infty { (y- m_T)^n \theta(x,y) \mathrm{d}y}</math> where the mean location, <math>m_T</math>, is given by: :<math> m_T = {1\over\beta^*}\int_0^\infty { y \theta(x,y) \mathrm{d}y}</math>
There are some advantages to also include descriptions of moments of the boundary layer profile derivatives with respect to the height above the wall. Consider the first derivative temperature profile central moments given by: :<math> {\epsilon_n} = \int_0^\infty { (y-{\beta^*})^n {d \theta(x,y) \over dy} \mathrm{d}y}</math> where the mean location is the thermal displacement thickness <math>\beta^*</math>.
Finally the second derivative temperature profile central moments are given by: :<math> {\phi_n} = \mu\int_0^\infty { (y-{\mu})^n {d^2 \theta(x,y) \over dy^2} \mathrm{d}y}</math> where the mean location, <math>\mu</math>, is given by: :<math> {1 \over \mu} = -\left( \frac{d\theta(x,y) }{d y}\right)_{y=0}</math>
With the moments and the thermal mean location defined, the boundary layer thickness and shape can be described in terms of the thermal boundary layer width ([[variance]]), thermal [[Skewness|skewnesses]], and thermal excess ([[Kurtosis|excess kurtosis]]). For the Pohlhausen solution for laminar flow on a heated flat plate,<ref>Schlichting, p. 292.</ref> it is found that thermal boundary layer thickness defined as <math>\delta_T = m_T + 4\sigma_T</math> where <math>\sigma_T=\kappa_2^{1/2}</math>, tracks the 99% thickness very well.<ref>Weyburne, 2018, p. 5.</ref>
For laminar flow, the three different moment cases all give similar values for the thermal boundary layer thickness. For turbulent flow, the thermal boundary layer can be divided into a region near the wall where thermal diffusion is important and an outer region where thermal diffusion effects are mostly absent. Taking a cue from the [[Boundary layer|boundary layer energy balance equation]], the second derivative boundary layer moments, <math>{\phi_n}</math> track the thickness and shape of that portion of the thermal boundary layer where [[thermal diffusivity]] <math>{\alpha }</math> is significant. Hence the moment method makes it possible to track and quantify the region where thermal diffusivity is important using <math>{\phi_n}</math> moments whereas the overall thermal boundary layer is tracked using <math>{\epsilon_n}</math> and <math>{\kappa_n}</math> moments.
Calculation of the derivative moments without the need to take derivatives is simplified by using integration by parts to reduce the moments to simply integrals based on the thermal displacement thickness kernel: :<math> {k_n}= \int_0^\infty {y^n\theta(x,y) \,\mathrm{d}y}</math> This means that the second derivative skewness, for example, can be calculated as: :<math>\gamma_{T} = \phi_3/\phi_2^{3/2} = (2\mu^3 - 6\beta^*\mu^2 + 6\mu k_1)/(-\mu^2 + 2\mu\beta^*)^{3/2} </math>
== Further reading == * Hermann Schlichting, ''Boundary-Layer Theory'', 7th ed., McGraw Hill, 1979. * Frank M. White, ''Fluid Mechanics'', McGraw-Hill, 5th Edition, 2003. * Amir Faghri, Yuwen Zhang, and John Howell, ''Advanced Heat and Mass Transfer'',Global Digital Press, {{ISBN|978-0-9842760-0-4}}, 2010.

== References == * Schlichting, Hermann (1979). ''Boundary-Layer Theory'', 7th ed., McGraw Hill, New York, U.S.A. * Weyburne, David (2006). "A mathematical description of the fluid boundary layer," Applied Mathematics and Computation, vol. 175, pp. 1675–1684 * Weyburne, David (2018). "New thickness and shape parameters for describing the thermal boundary layer," arXiv:1704.01120[physics.flu-dyn]

{{Infobox company | name = Whittle Shortline | logo = | type = [[Privately held company]] | foundation = 1997 | location = [[Louisiana, Missouri]] | key_people = Mike Whitworth | area_served = | industry = [[Manufacturing]], [[Retailing|retail]] | products = [[Wooden toy train]]s | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.woodentrain.com Whittle Shortline Railroad] | footnotes = }} '''Whittle Shortline''' is a [[toy]] company owned and operated in the [[United States]].
== History ==
During the mid-1990s, former [[US Air Force]] pilot Mike Whitworth received a compound [[mitre saw]] as a gift from his wife, ostensibly for doing [[home improvement]] projects.
The saw sat unused for almost two years, when Whitworth got the inspiration to produce toy trains for friends and family. By 1997, word of his craftsmanship had reached local retailers, who in turn asked that he make the wooden trains on a professional basis.
In 1999 the production moved from the family home some miles to the historic building of the [[Frisco Hotel]] in [[Valley Park, Missouri|Valley Park]], a suburb of [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]]. By 2005 most of the production was moved north to the city of Louisiana, Missouri.
In the recent wake of the [[2007 Chinese export recalls|recalls]] of many Chinese-made consumer goods (including toys),<ref>{{cite news|url = http://wowktv.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=25363|title = Recall on Thomas the Tank Engine Toys|author = Gil McClanahan | date = 2007-06-19|work = WOWK-TV| accessdate = 2008-11-29}}</ref> Whittle Shortline have seen a heightening of interest in their products.
== Products == [[Image:Toytrain.jpg|thumb|right|A colorful engine patterned from a [[Chessie System]] [[EMD GP40-2|GP40-2]], one of many wooden toy trains offered by Whittle Shortline.]] Wooden toy trains and accessories are their specialty. These are non-motorized, and suitable for children. The cars and [[locomotive]]s [[Railway coupling|couple]] together using small [[magnet]]s, and are easy to manipulate. Whittle Shortline differ from their peers in that most of their trains are patterned from [[prototype]] [[North America]]n [[railroad]] equipment. The company proudly state their products as being '[[Made in the USA]]'.
The high quality woods used make Whittle Shortline toys more expensive than many other brands that use the same type of track. However, they are compatible with brands such as [[BRIO]] and [[Thomas the Tank Engine]].
Aside from their standard line of wooden trains, Whittle Shortline also offer special versions of their toys.
=== Holiday car series === Each year since 2002, the company has offered a freight car decorated in a colorful [[holiday]] theme aimed at collectors. Typically featuring a [[boxcar]], although the 2002 and 2005 release saw a gift-adorned [[flatcar]] and [[hot cocoa]]-themed [[Tank car|tanker car]], respectively.
=== The Little Engine That Could === In 2006, the company released a wooden toy train line based upon [[The Little Engine That Could]], as a domestic alternative to [[Thomas the Tank Engine]].
=== Mega Trains === Whittle Shortline introduced in 2007 a line of 'Mega Trains'. These featured greatly enlarged locomotives and rolling stock, while retaining compatibility with standard wooden track.
